reviewText:
Early Access Review

Being a huge fan of horror games, I absolutely had to pick up Layers of Fear.
As described it as a “psychedelic horror” game, as you play a painter who is feverishly attempting to complete a true masterpiece, while going mad in the process.

“Every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of the artist, not of the sitter.” ~ Oscar Wilde

The game mechanics are incredibly refreshing, as there was no specific villain you were trying to escape from, for the most part, which meant that the 'environment' was what you needed to fear, including several jump scares along your way.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=519450951

Atmospherically, Layers of Fear is astounding from the moment you enter the house you will be exploring. Rain is falling heavily outside, with occasional bursts of thunder crackling behind you. The entire game is influenced by art and décor from previous centuries, particularly the architecture and design of the 19th century, and the visuals are very well tied together with this theme.
What also worth mentioning is the incredibly alluring and chilling soundtrack during the gameplay, that gives you the emotions the situation pulls you in.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sB_6mk-XTw

I’d recommend the game to anyone who enjoys horror games as a genre, particularly if you don’t mind games where you can’t defend yourself and it’s all about you, the antagonist, and the spooky atmosphere.
Despite the game 'still' being in Early Access, what IS available to play is deeply engaging, if in need of a little polish here and there.
The game relies heavily on its ability to set you on edge, so if you’re the type with nerves of steel you likely won’t get too much out of it. To horror fans, however? I wholeheartedly recommend Layers of Fear to you!



9/10

Early Access Review

THIS GAME IS TERRIFYING!

To be completely honest, I was nearly scared into a coma by this game.
Layers of Fear offers a truly immersive horror experience. The story takes you on a tour through the mind of a madman. As you progress, you find clues that give you details about life of the character before he went crazy. I actually had chills during certain areas of the game. The environment is constantly changing around you, and you never know what is waiting for you at the next turn.

I would definitely suggest picking this game up while it is in EA (Early Access). I was left hanging because the game is unfinished. The cool thing about being a part of this game while it is in EA is that the game is constantly changing. You can help the developers iron out the kinks and help make this game better. Plus, you get the game much cheaper than people who will purchase the full game when it is released.

I cannot wait to see where the developers take this story! Even though it is unfinished, I consider this game a horror masterpiece!

column20:
letter or newspaper clipping that is used to fill in the backstory. Sadly most of you will guess the direction the story is headed within the first five minutes of gameplay. Thankfully Layers of Fear doesn't go for more exposition than is needed to reach its conclusion and should take most gamer's roughly about 3 hours to complete from beginning to end.

Layers of Fear also attempts to introduce some puzzle elements at six key locations in the house that will require solving in order to retrieve an item that will help you complete the painting you have started but also act as items that drive the story forward. They are not particularly challenging with the solution often to simply just walk around the room activating whatever the cursor highlights until the item becomes visible. Graphically Layers of Fear looks incredible with some very highly detailed models and environments. When I saw that the game was made using Unity I was even more surprised given that a lot of indie developers use it with minimal effect to churn out utter rubbish. I played the game on a laptop using a 680M GPU and the game ran near flawlessly at 60FPS on High Detail for the most part (the only place I noticed severe drops in frames was when you find yourself submerged under water towards the end of the game).

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=627135390
Layers of Fear is an interesting experiment. Using the profession of a painter with his art being the very thing that causes his world to collapse from the inside out is one half entertaining and visually striking and the other half dreary and dull as dirty dishwater. As a pure horror title though - Layers of Fear is unfortunately lacking in what every single horror title needs the most - a pulse. I would still definitely recommend playing through it once since you can complete it in an afternoon and some of the visual tricks the game employs to move the story along are certainly creative and worth experiencing but I wouldn't pay full price for it. During a sale - definitely

I'm going to start this right off the bat by saying this is by far one of the best horror games I've ever played. I cannot get enough of it. It's a bit slow paced at first, but it builds you up for all that's to come - and does an amazing job at that thus far.

Now I, and most people, have come accross a bug in which a room just goes pitch black - causing you to go back to the menu and then back to the game. A bit of a drawback, but can be fixed nonetheless. This game outshines most games and I just cannot recommend it enough. If you're an avid horror fan looking to add something new to your library, this is it.

10/10 buy this game naow.

Layers of Fear is incredibly unpredictable and because everything just comes together so nicely, you're constantly on alert; I have yet to come across a game that does that so smoothly and efficiently as this one. You're in for one hell of a ride if you get this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In my waking dreams I see it – mocking me, challenging me. Is it my fault then, imperfect as I am, that I cannot give it life; that it must exist on an ideal plane, mocked as I am by its twisted, deranged lessers? But this tragedy, this pain, this torture... this tribulation has opened my eyes – so wide that they well with bloody tears; strained and blurred, still I see it clear as day. I've used the wrong tools, the wrong canvas. My paints I'll replace with blood; my canvas with flesh.

This... this I am owed.

Immortality will elude me no longer.

I'm not going to beat around the bush ladies and gentlemen – THIS, this is currently the best horror game of 2015, the horror game to beat – and Early Access only means it will (hopefully, ideally) get better. It's moody, atmospheric, and subtly terrifying before abruptly cranking the spooky dial to 11. It's graphically and audibly on par with the much-lauded PT. It is, much like an onion, layered.

It's spectacular.

You are an artist hit hard by tragedies, drowning your sorrows in booze. Your art, a reflection of your crippled, troubled soul becomes so twisted, dark, and deranged that even your friends are rejecting your macabre pieces. As you explore your beautifully furnished, turn-of-the-19th-century home you'll find newspaper clips and scattered mementos that fill in the narrative. And you'd be remiss to shrug this title off as “just another walking simulator,” though it initially smacks of that. Very little happens at first as you explore; the gameplay primarily consists of opening, inspecting, collecting, etc.

If you're anything like me you'll just gawk your way through each room. Layers of Fear is as beautiful and nuanced as the Renaissance and Baroque period paintings hanging in the artist's home – limited asset recycling, great lighting, varied colors... it's like you're playing a still life painting.

And the sound is great. As your player character wobbles from room to room you hear the creaking of the floorboard, the crashing of glass, the wailing of women, and more sinister orchestrations. Some moments are accented with shrill “horror” chords, and others leave you to silently contemplate what you've just seen. It's masterfully executed and should be commended, perhaps moreso than the graphical power. It really, truly is immersive.


Most importantly it is SCARY. I started off ♥♥♥♥♥ure, walking through every room, picking up every item, confidently flinging doors wide open with nary a glance over my shoulder. But slowly the pieces fall together and you'll start seeing things. Was that graffiti always on the wall? And that portrait? Surely the subject's face wasn't always so... pained? And I was sure I left that door wide open. Like the very artist you play you'll begin to watch the world melt around you, unsure of your own mental health. What's real and what isn't? What horrors befell this man (who looks eerily like Sir Anthony Hopkins), and what horrors has he committed in the pursuit of artistic perfection?

It starts out atmospherically heavy, drawing you into a false sense of security. And the moment you put your down guard things seem to scurry around you. It uses a few jumpscares, yes, but usually to cut the tension of an excruciatingly long buildup. It's jumpscares done right - at the behest of the atmosphere.

Is Layers of Fear a worthy investment? I think so. The developers have stated it's 75% completed (it certainly looks and plays the part). And they're adamant about listening to the community for suggestions, which is a bit of a double edged sword. But based on what they've presented I have no doubt that this project is in skilled, loving hands... the hands of a sculptor, one might say, who can see the subject in the stone even before setting to work.

I'm thoroughly impressed, as this year so far has been kind of lackluster with the horror releases. I believe, sincerely, that Layers of Fear broke the horror drought we've suffered for so long.

And with waters rising who knows what will float up from the depths?

Edit: And for what it's worth this game has the BEST, most frustrated, most ominous knocking I've heard in a game since Eternal Darkness. It is persistent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Heavily inspired by The picture of Dorian Grey authored by Oscar Wilde.

As the description says, you take the role of an artist who is travelling through his house on a mission to finish his masterpiece, as you progress through the game, its begins to become darker & much more twisted, revealing bits and pieces of the storyline to you over time.

Pros

- Extremely immersive in terms of visual & audial prowess, the creators of this game dedicated alot of time towards ensuring it caem out looking & sounding gorgeous, not only that, but the amount of detail that has been put into the artwork and architecture really portrays some amazing talent within the fields.

- Immaculateley timed. The creators of this game have tried and tested every scare tactic. Theres is a perfect mix between jump scares & drawn out horror. Play this game at night alone and you will s**t yourself.

- Extremely well done storyline. The game offers you insights towards what has occured yet it manages to hold off the suspense by adding twists that you would never expect, ensuring that you will not be able to fully guess the plot until the very end of the game.

Cons

- There are a few graphical bugs, though not that many. Antialiasing is a problem at the moment as you will tend to notice most objects surrounding your character are jagged at the edges.

Altogether this game is a must have, the concept is fantastically original. It is definetley worth the 13 USD if you are a fan of survival horror, for it is a game that you shall never forget.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Don't believe what you see on your first sight...Note: This game is still in early access and not finished. You won't be able to play through the whole game in the current state. Don't let it scare you off. Why? You'll find out in this review.

▐▐░░▒▒▓▓ Review ▓▓▒▒░░▐▐

In Layers of Fear everything revolves around a famous painter. Without any sightable goal he explores his mansion, but step by step the madness seizes the painter and everything around him changes into nightmarish scenes. Something seems to be following his steps and yet it's not certain if it will harm him and tries to lead him into the deep insanity ... might it be the madness itself?

Storytelling and gameplay reminds a lot about Amnesia: A machine for pigs. Neither an inventory nor difficult puzzles will put obstacles in your way. You might just lean back and enjoy the deep atmosphere of the game while discovering the huge mansion. But nothing is like it seems. Rooms change within an eyeblink and some events even force you to break the rule #1 in horror games: to not look behind you. With the feeling that every minute something might happen you wouldn't dare to look back, would you?
Nevertheless, this game will not leave you stumble aimless in the dark. On your exploration you will find news articles and letters which will reveal the reason behind the madness of the painter.

The graphics are well made and emphasize the deep atmosphere with high-definition textures and a stunning ambient illumination. Sounds and music give the atmosphere the final touch and suck you deep into the mad mind of that man with no name.

Even the controls have the same mechanic like in Amnesia and Penumbra. With the left mousebutton hold and the movement of your mouse you can open and close doors, chests and everything else that might reveale more about the whole story. Easy to get into it you will enjoy the storytelling even more.

▐▐░░▒▒▓▓ To cut the long story short ▓▓▒▒░░▐▐

Not every horror game creates an atmosphere that keeps me playing forward. Yet still unfinished and not possible to play through the whole story it let me wait impatient to know about more. If you like Amnesia and Penumbra, you will like this piece of good work too. Don't have expectations for a game filled with challenging puzzles; you will be disappointed. For now the entrance to the chamber of horros might cost you 10$ but with the hope that the developer will continue on the story it is worth every single penny.

Darken your room, put your headphones on and enjoy the nightmarish trip through the mind of a mad man.

▐▐░░▒▒▓▓ Scoring ▓▓▒▒░░▐▐

Gameplay: 8.0/10.0
Graphics: 9.0/10.0
Controls: 10.0/10.0 (Schematics of Amnesia/Penumbra)
Sounds: 10.0/10.0
Game length: In the current state 2 hours; finished game: N/A
Recommendable: Horror enthusiasts and fans from Amnesia / Penumbra will love this.

All in all: 9.0/10.0

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Highly recommend this game as it is yet another example of the potential games have to immerse the player in a world unlike their own. And in Layers of Fear, the world you're taken to is full of darkness and insanity that lingers in the walls and bleeds through the carpet, beckoning you onwards throughout the game to taste its sweet horror.

Many of the comments point out how scary this game is. Personally, I agree it is scary but not like Amnesia scary (which on my scale is utterly terrifying). This game has a constant undertone of darkness and a nightmarish quality that bares its teeth all throughout the game, with moments of heightened terror which truly make the experience worthwhile while not being too terribly scary to be unable to play through it.

The voiceover, trinkets, and pieces of correspondence that you discover throughout the game provide a very well-rounded way of understanding the madness that struck the artist and how his colleagues around him reacted. The soundtrack is superb, and at one point I had to stop momentarily to enjoy the piece that played over a particular part of the game.

Overall, Layers of Fear overflows with beauty and tragedy, and I'm glad to have been able to experience this piece of art. To the developers: You're one of the good ones. Thank you for your ongoing contribution to indie games.

I'd say this is a must play, and now that it's finished, you're looking at 2 or so hours of great horror gaming well worth your time and money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Layers of Fear is a horror adventure game that delves into the twisted mind of a troubled painter and his descent to madness. One thing I’ve notice the game does right is the pacing of the story. It starts of slow, depicting an earlier and happier life of the protagonist, introducing key objects and areas that will become central to the story later on. Gradually, the terror is introduced, first as harmless dissolving paintings, then to the ghastly apparition of his supposedly dearly departed wife.

It’s great to see an early access horror game actually terrify me because I absolutely love the disturbing atmosphere and the tension I’ve felt traversing through the shifting and looping corridors of this mad painter’s house. The game is riddled with jumpscares, I’ll give you that one and I grew numb to them by the 3rd time but the game doesn’t solely rely on jumpscares to scare you. It incorporates sounds as a way to rattle you. Whether it is the haunting laughter of a distant woman or the mocking giggles of children, to the peaceful pieces of classical music, these sounds alerts the player and puts them on edge.

There are barely any puzzles so this first person narrative is all you have but it isn’t exactly a walking simulator. There are notes to collect, objects to find that trigger memories and rooms that paint a story of the painter’s history.  I can’t say there’s much to explore since the game does lead you to where you need to go anyways so it is pretty much a linear game but it is enjoyable walking through the hallways of the painter’s home and see what has change since it does loop around (similar to PT, if you've played it).

Unfortunately, there are some optimization problems even though the graphics are pretty to look at (slows down in some parts i.e. the kitchen area) but nothing a few patches can’t solve. The early access only show about half of the game (from what I can tell) and I managed to complete it in an hour and half so I can’t imagine the full game will be too long. Then again, I can’t be certain since it’s not complete yet. I know some people aren’t keen on buying into an Early Access game but I bought it at a discount and I don’t regret my purchase.

TL:DR

Pros:
-	Great, eerie atmosphere
-	Excellent pacing of the story
-	Good sounds and music
-	Pretty graphics

Cons:
-	Not complete yet since it is still in Early Access
-	Optimization problems
-	Jumpscares (I didn’t like them…)
-	The slow pacing at the beginning might turn off some people
-  Linear

Thanks for reading and when you have the time, here’s my video of me fooling around in Layers of Fear. A word of caution, the more I talked, the more panicked I was feeling XD

reviewText:
Layers of Fear is a first person adventure horror game, developed by Blooper Team, and published by Aspyr Media. The game was released in February 2016 on PC, PS4 and Xbox One. This is probably the most notable title to come out of the Polish based development studio.

You take on the role of a 19th century painter, aiming to finish his masterpiece. You follow the harrowing tale of this man who struggles with mental illness which leads you down a troubled path into his mind along the way. The game is split into 6 chapters, each chapter’s aim is to find a key item that helps you complete your masterpiece. Whilst the main story is fairly linear, you do get chances to break off the main path to explore the dark and spooky manor in which the game takes place in. You will be able to find family heirlooms which contains snippets of extra plot for you to delve deeper into this ghostly plot. The exploration portion of Layers of Fear reminded me a lot of Outlast – the way you explore rooms and navigate around the world has many similarities. There isn’t a combat system in Layers of Fear, again like Outlast, but this is because you won’t really run into any combat facing scenarios. You will come up against your foes, but these will be part of scripted events which you cannot escape or bypass from.

As you would expect from any Adventure game, the puzzles are your standard “horror style”, that usually involve the use of candles, dead babies and dolls, blood written on walls to reveal codes for lock doors and many more. I really enjoyed working out the resolution to all of the puzzles throughout, and was pleasantly surprised with myself when I did it all unaided without a walkthrough.  Some of the puzzles were sadly marred with technical problems, which resulted in me needing to load from a previous check point, because simple things like objects that you need to move, suddenly stop being able to be moved. These small technical issues grew a little tiresome towards the latter chapters as game’s checkpoint system is not the best to say the least.

The graphics in Layers of Fear look spectacular – the game is built on the Unity 3D engine so the highly details character models and locations were brought to life. The scares use of lighting is used perfectly as it leads you down an even darker path throughout the game.  The manor you are exploring is filled with creepy art work on the walls, which are well worth the time just to check out.

The game took me just over four hours to complete, I managed this in on sitting which is something to be noted as I often find adventure games like this to be slow paced and I usually need to break it up into multiple sessions. The game’s pacing right from the start is slow, but you are able to take the game at your own speed. If you want to spend an extra fifteen minutes exploring the house, go right ahead, it’s not going to deter you the path, however if you choose not to, you won’t be missing key plot points by skipping over the extra lore items that can be found.

Layers of Fear does offer alternative endings; these are done by playing the game in certain ways, for instance not picking up the hidden secrets throughout a play through will unlock a special ending; this encourages players to do more than one run and will reward them rightly so at the end.

I would have to say Layers of Fear has been a brilliant adventure game that hit all the sweet spots for any horror story. The game is owned by over 100K players, so it has been accepted by the wider audience, and rightly so. It’s hard to find fault with many aspects of this game, and the price tag is fairly targeted for a game with plenty of replay value.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here and checking out the TeamTom Review site[teamtomreviews.co.uk]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh wow. This. Is. Scary.
It truly is, and I thoroughly enjoying my time in game. This is beautifully executed, and relies much less on jumpscares than many other games. There are some, and they are pretty decent, but what takes the cake is the feeling of insanity holding your character firmly in its grip.
the house is like some kind of hell, confusing, scary, full of secrets and hidden things. Sometimes it's like some kind of bad trip. Walk into a room. Nothing in there. Turn around, the door is gone.
There are some insanely (literally) cool ideas here... some scenes for example related to a still-life of fruit, or a piano in a basement. You will see, if you keep going.

Also, the game is quite unpredictable. Sometimes you are absolutely positive there'll be some kind of a cliché jumpscare hitting you.And it doesn't. But then, when you don't expect it, something totally crazy will happen.

Also, slowly but surely, through newspapers, monologues, things you find, you get an idea that there is a totally HORRIBLE backstory to the character, his family and his house. Wait until you start unlocking the secrets related to your current painting.

Even though there is no direct reference, I find myself thinking of Lovecraft-style horror, not only because of the old school vibe of the house, but because the game sometimes only HINTS at terrible things, instead of showing them to the tiniest detail. The atmosphere creeps you out, makes you imagine what is behind all this, even though you haven't even seen a lot yet.

The game is not at all open world in any sense of the world. It's very much on rails, dictating where you go, and there isn't a ton of interaction with items, no inventory etc. (mostly, you pick up keys or items for your painting)
It's weird, it's mysterious, it's nutty, sometimes yucky, it's scary, shocking, yet very beautiful.
Big gratz to the developers who really came up with some killer ideas, and created a VERY scary, immersive and atmospheric game. Up for a scare? Something that's not about cheap jumpscares and more about getting an idea of how someone goes insane, with all the weirdness and unpredictable, irrational stuff involved? Get. This. Game.

If you play it with headphones (recommended by the devs) and lights off...don't say I didn't warn you.
9/10, even in this early state

NOTE: I have yet to complete this game. I'm coming back to it nightly and throwing in the next session. I'm writing this because I keep seeing very annoying >greentext reviews and it's sh***y so, on with the review.

Horror games have been having a lot of trouble, as of late. They are usually very gimmicky and often times extremely predictable. Very little do we see actual psychological horror done correctly anymore. The last two horror games I have loved have been Outlast: Whistleblower and Amnesia: The Dark Descent. There's a bit of a time gap there. And before that, it was Silent Hill 2 so we've been lacking in good horror games. I miss the Oh, sh*t moments of games like Condemned: Criminal Origins when paths were being blocked behind you and mannequins had replaced that open space to loosen you up with unease before a hobo attacked you. Sound silly? Well, it is until you're playing it. But it hadn't much been tried before that and it was delivered well. The originality of it payed off.

Now, where does Layers of Fear come in? Psychological Horror brought back to form. Think back to the Silent Hill series. Yes, many were terrible but I still remember the moment when I realized, This f**king staircase is infinite..." and turned around. column19:
it's definitely anything but dull and boring. Most of the game revolves around the mechanic of things changing behind your back while you're not looking. The entire experience is played out without a single loading screen, and this entire idea is pulled off extremely well. That being said, if you find it difficult to maneuver the world and control the camera angles in 3D games, this one may simply not be for you. Many of the scares require you to look at a certain place at a certain time, which is quite easy to do if you're used to video games, but if you aren't so good with 3D, the full effect of the game may be lost on you.

Now let's talk about the scares themselves -  you can't have a good horror game without it being scary, right? Now let me say just one thing: this game is absolutely terrifying. If it isn't the scariest game I've ever played, then it's still in my top 3, no questions asked. The gorgeous graphics and flawless sound design create a gripping atmosphere at all times, and there was never a moment in the entire campaign where I wasn't on the edge of my seat, waiting to see what was going to happen next. The best thing this game has going for it is that it's original. While games like Outlast (2013) had you running away from horrific beasts in gruesome locations, Layers Of Fear's horror is very different. Some may say that Layers is filled with cheap jumpscares, but it really isn't. While the jumps are frequent, it's really the psychedelic aspect that brought out the fear in me. It's extremely difficult to explain how the scares work in this game, but even the trailers don't do it justice. This game will have you spinning in circles and watching the entire room change with every rotation. It's no joke. The jumpscares, along with the psychedelic elements and the changing rooms behind every door, will have you trembling each time you open a door at night for weeks. Not to mention that the game generally moves at a brisk pace, with a kind of BOOM scare, move to next room, BOOM another scare, etc etc, which makes it all the more terrifying each time you run away from something right into something else. I wouldn't watch too many videos on this game before playing it to get a feel for what I'm saying though, because when you see all the scares a room has to offer before you enter it, they can be a little less exciting.

Unfortunately, there were a few moments in the game where doing something can become ever so slightly tedious or repetitive (THE PART WITH THE CHECKERBOARD NEAR THE END OH MY GOD), which pulls you out of the moment. In a game that's very atmosphere-centric, this can be a problem, if not only a minor one. It's also worth mentioning that the game features quite a few cleverly designed puzzles that feel challenging, but never unfair. One thing I didn't like about the update to the final game was that it added female narrative along with the player's own thoughts, which made it seem less introspective and personal. The fact that there was only one actual character with a voice actor in the game made it feel quite lonely and added to the experience. Although this is only an opinion, I feel it was important to add for the sake of being thorough.

TL;DR/OVERVIEWOveral Score: 9/10
All in all, Layers Of Fear is a horror game I know I won't soon forget. With a completely original concept (something the horror genre overall has been lacking lately), unique scare tactics, clever puzzles and a fantastic atmosphere, Bloober Team has definitely hit the nail on the head with this one. The game is also highly replayable, as there are hundreds of cabinets to open and tons of things to find, as well as rooms that you can't visit by playing through the game only once.

+ Unique Concept
+ Great Atmosphere
+ Original Scares
+ Fast-Paced
+ No Loading Screens // Very Fluid
+ Emotional Story
+ Replay Value
+ Looks Fantastic
? Occasional Female Narrative
- Maybe Too Many Openable Cabinets?
- Can Be Slightly Repetitive At Times
- Short Campaign (Approx. 3-4 hours)
- Slightly Anticlimactic Ending

Is This Game For Me?This game IS for you if...
- You enjoyed the concept shown by the trailers, screenshots and description
- You desire something new and original within the horror genre
- You are able to immerse yourself in a video game
- You don't relate to any of the traits in the This game is NOT for you if..." section

This game is NOT for you if...
- You are prone to photosensitive seizures or nausea
- You find it difficult to maneuver in 3D games
- You have a heart condition that may be affected by jumpscares
- You feel like the idea/concept is stupid

reviewText:
Take P.T., Eraserhead, Picture of Dorian Gray, Jan Svankmajer (google him), and an art history textbook. Put them in a blender with a heavy dose of optical illusions and shadows. Garnish with a paprika of some pretty good jump-scares. That's this game.  A 3 hour victorian themed take on 'what if P.T. were a full game.' I mean that in a good way because this is a very obviously lovingly crafted experience built around gameplay ideas in the infamous P.T./Silent Hills demo.

Pros:
-Amazing visuals, including some really cool optical illusion stuff.
-Gloriously dreadful atmosphere.
-Very nice sound design (play with surround sound headphones if you can - the bass is a big deal at some parts)
-Some genuine jump-scares that got my adrenaline pumping against my will.
-Amazing payoff at the ending with some really cool animation.
-Didn't experience any bugs except an extremely minor one after the ending just before the credit rolls. (A cabinet suddenly teleported closed while I had my head wedged looking in it.)
-The first time I've ever been unnerved by receiving an achievement.  (You will know which one I am talking about when you get it.)

Cons:
-Much of the writing in the backstory items and dialogue is unconvincing and doesn't sound authentically period at all. For a game with so much attention to detail, this stood out as disappointing for me.
-Some puzzles grind the game to a halt for a bit, leaving you doing some boring pixel-hunting for numbers you might have overlooked, and repeating a particular part as you do.
-Some cheap eye-rolling unscary scares.
-Lapses into cliche in its story quite a lot. I also feel like a much meatier story could have elevated this game more.
-Only 3 hours long. It's a good and memorable 3 hours, but for $20 some people may want to wait till a sale. I got it because it has subject matter up my alley (art history nerd) so you may want to get it for the same reasons I did tho.

Overall: 4/5 - I want to see this studio make more games like this (or other genres of fiction than horror for a narrative game if they're keen for it) and get better at making them.

reviewText:
TL;DR
Layers of Fear is a psychedelic horror story where you play as a deranged artist who can't quite seem to remember the layout of his house.

Pros
+excellent graphics
+excellent art direction
+excellent sound direction
+excellent atmosphere

Cons
- very short
- shock value wears off in the 2nd half

Layers of Fear starts off with a slow self narrated doublespeak exclaiming a hopelessness in his situation, with only one way to bring it all back...'Finish it' he mutters to himself as you hear rain and lightning droning in the background. Keys clanking onto metal, you hear sounds of a door opening, you are brought to attention from the pitch black screen to a scene of a mansion. You are now in control of the main character, whom you know absolutely nothing about until you explore the depths of the mansion, rummaging through every single drawer and cabinet looking for notes scattered about to give you an inkling of an idea of who the main character may be.

Early on you find out that the character is an artist, or at least was an artist sometime in the 19th century. You have the freedom to explore the mansion and it's room which are heavily Victorian in nature. A creepy piano piece plays in the background, that perfectly captures the mood of the set piece. You're alone in a giant mansion during a thunderstorm, the place feels eerily perfect, not a speck of dust can be found. You come across an easel covered by cloth. As you slowly reveal the unfinished painting, the room subtly changes. A message is sprawled on the exit that wasn't there before, 'GET IT RIGHT THIS TIME'. You go through the door, and suddenly the mansion has transformed itself. A mist of fog rises from the floor, doors lock behind you never to reopen again. The ambient tones of the soundtrack slowly haunting you as you hesitantly move forward through the rooms.

Layers of Fear introduction perfectly encapsulates a mysteriousness that had me paralyzed. Enraptured by the setting and the fear of what was to come next, it all felt vividly real. Especially with how beautiful the set pieces were room to room. On ultra settings, it's very easy to marvel at your surroundings with it's soft shadows reflecting off the dim lighted halls throughout. It's as pretty as a picture, as if it were carefully sculpted by the artist himself. The artist seems to have an obsession with perfection as when you listen to an auditory flashback of when he finds his muse, his proposal comes off eerily strange in retrospect. He wanted to put his name on the most beautiful woman in the world, just like the rest of his paintings . His object of affection was beauty at it's core, but what happens when the beauty fades?

As you find out, one way or another the beauty has faded from his life. And once it does, so does his inspiration for painting. He hits a giant roadblock which is expressed visually within the game. You the player, has to help the painter find just the right items to help him finish his masterpiece. But the house isn't what it once seemed, closed off walls will appear where they were once open hallways. You will go in circles and circles while the game will openly remind you through scrawled writings on the wall. The artist's inner narrative uses his house's walls as the canvas, giving you insight as to how he feels on his deranged journey to reclaiming his lost inspiration. They seem like ramblings of a madman at first but subtly aid you to progress in the game.

The mansion's are like the inner frameworks of his mind, cluttered and confusing. Neverending, yet constantly closing the paths behind you. What was once a simple mansion is now an endless mind palace that transforms at his whims, with his deepest fears manifesting , clouding the golden years where he was once hailed as a genius. The mansion from Layers of Fears strikingly resembles a similar theme from a book called House of Leaves by Mark Z. Danielewski. In the novel, the house initially has larger internal measurements than external. Over time, the interior of the house seems to slowly expand until a hallway appears that should lead outside to where the yard is but does not. The interesting aspect is that the book also has an unusual page layout and style, making it visually surrealist in it's own way.

Layers of Fears feels like it's takes this surrealist form one step further and perfects the execution using it's strong visual tricks and audial cues. Walls will shift, hallways will reverse, invert, making each room feel slightly familiar yet alien to both the player and the painter. Misdirection is key here, something Layers of Fears pulls of meticulously. The game will consistently find new ways to surprise you visually with it's metamorphic atmosphere, and this is only accomplished by the player being a witness to the painter's madness.

This is the majority of what you'll be doing all game, exploring dark dreary rooms for notes and items that will help you on your quest to finish a painting. Although it would be categorized as a exploration game, it feels more like an on rails horror set. Once you're finished with a room, you can never go back making you feel like a puppet being dragged from A to B with very little to interact with except a couple drawers or shelves to find notes about past events in no real chronological order. It's mainly up to the player to decide how badly he wants to find out what's really happening in the game by opening 100s of drawers in hopes of finding more notes. You never truly feel like a player in the game interacting with the world, more like another set piece that the artist has created for you to be a witness into his madness. It's when the game does take complete control away from you, does it feel truly unique. Helpless to the panorama of horrors slowly settling closer and closer, claustrophobia settling in to the point helplessness. Your control is truly gone, you are no longer a player but a set piece just as much the painter is and it feels wonderfully surreal.

The second and final act of the game delves heavily into psychedelic hallucinatory levels, where set pieces transform before you into sublimely grotesque imaginations of the painter. The problem is that the shock value of the similar jump scares have worn off at this point, and that I have absolutely nothing to fear. The first time I encounter a monster roaming the hallways, I'm terrified by the games brilliant usage of the lighting system. But you soon quickly realize that there's nothing to be done about them. The hallways are always narrow and small and the doors lock behind you so you have no choice but to either wait and see or just walk towards them and brave the brunt of their psychological attack. Once you realize that it almost feels like your 'death' is a plot progressor. This removes probably the most vital 'layer of fear' within the game. Once the element of fear is taken away, and replaced with plot progress you're no longer traumatized by their appearance but considering a quick death to move on. While you continue to march forward to find the final piece of puzzle to put the story all together, the ambiguous and surrealist nature never quite grants you that clear resolution rather leaving it up to the player's interpretation by how many notes he found throughout the short three hour game.

Overall Layers of Fear is a technical marvel that is both hauntingly beautiful and surreptitiously ambiguous in nature. While the ambiguity drives the narrative forward through the character's interpretation of the artist's evocative imaginings of his mansion, the game slowly loses it's pulse of mysteriousness through the over use of jump scare tropes and identical monster encounters but never it's beauty. I recommend Layers of Fear to players who want an exploration based game who don't mind letting their imagination run wild and want to enjoy a fresh surrealist take on the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an early access game so the review will change again once it is fully released"
Layers of Fear is a very different horror experience. Instead of focusing on jump scares using monsters it uses it's own unique horror. It actually does this very well and I have to say it's probably the most scared I have ever been at a horror game.

The horror this game focuses on is a psychedelic kind of horror. While exploring the house you will experience changing scenery and corridors without you even looking. You often find when turning around that you are now in a completely different room to where you was before. What this does is it creates a fear of turning around. Literally one of my biggest fears while playing was turning around because you never have any idea what you are gonna find. I also never found myself looking behind the curtains as such by seeing the walls change myself.

They then obviously had to include jump scares. This is more often than not done by ways of paintings. They often dissolve or mold into something else more scary. These jump scares I find rather unique and I loved them. But then the game also throws in a lot of cheap jump scares. These include things like pots being thrown at a wall and slamming doors. Although they definitely did scare me I find them rather boring and uninspired. I just felt like they needed something to fill the time spent exploring.

The game also features a story. It tells a rather disturbing story of a man and his wife which I won't spoil. I'll just say you may cringe listening to some of it. It is told in a kinda "gone home" style. This means by picking up items you will learn more about the story. Some is through reading extracts and others you will hear the main character reminiscing about the past. I will also add here that the actor is incredible with his voice work. Some people may be put off by this way of story telling but to me
recommended:
I also loved this storytelling choice.

The story is also open to interpretation I believe. Soemtimes the game is rather vague in these story extracts. It's probably quite meaningfully doing this so you can yourself interpret the story how you want. The game doesn't always tell the story in a logical order of events. This story isn't complete yet so i can't say how I feel about an ending.

Layers of fear does seem to have a goal. You are seemingly building up a painting. We don't yet know what the painting will represent but it is definitely looking disturbing. To build this painting you will have to find items around the house to paint with. These aren't your regular painting items and you end up finding stuff like bones to paint with. Yep quite disturbing.

One thing people may dislike is that Layers of Fear is an almost entirely linear experience. For the first kind of 10 minutes of the game you are able to freely explore the house. After this you are locked into the games linear routes. If you don't like linear games then this isn't for you.

A problem I have is that sometimes the experience didn't seem to quite flow. I mean sometimes the soundtrack didn't flow into each other and the events seemed to just be random without any real meaning to why they were happening. I think going forward this game needs to try and make events link together to make it slightly more fun and horrifying.

The big problem I have with Layers of Fear comes later in the game. Notice how earlier I was saying I loved the unique way of horror they use and how they don't use monsters. Well this isn't entirely true. Near to the end of the current experience a monster is introduced. The monster seems to become the heart of the experience from there on. I think they should really consider removing this monster and crafting more of the unique horror experience in it's place instead. It may be scary but I don't think it really has a place in this game.

Graphics wise I had no problems whatsoever. The art style isn't unique by any means but what it does with the art style is definitely unique. Performance was Ok. It varied between 30-60 fps on my mid range system. It could probably do with some optimization.

Overall Layers of Fear really freaked me out and is the most scared I think i've ever been at a horror game. It's unique version of horror is what really makes it stand out. It took me just over 90 minutes to complete it in it's current entirety which may be a little short. However the price point is really cheap at £6.99 so I think it's worth it. I definitely look forward to play more of it but I hope they consider some of the changes I proposed.

reviewText: Layers of Fear is a good example of how scares should be implemented in a predictable setting. With a broad range of traditional scares, it strives to terrorize the player with as many different tricks as possible. For some, it will be overwhelming, and perhaps the game could have provided more downtime—or at least something more substantial than searching through empty drawers for notes. Replaying the adventure results in a severe decrease in terror because the story plays out nearly identically. However, that does not change the fact that Layers of Fear will send shivers down your spine during its first attempt, thanks to many careful jump scares. With a steady increase in terror, Layers of Fear is a horror game that succeeds through its variety.\n\nRead full review[www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText:
I can safely say, that this is one of my favourite horror games of the last few years.

I do believe it may be partly inspired by P.T, the Konami PS4 teaser, as the way things out of view change around you at times is very similar. The atmostphere in the game is very well crafted and you always feel on edge. This is in part due to brilliant sound design and creepy atmosphere and the imagery which is really quite something special and one of the strongest points of this game. You never quite know what freaky crap is going to happen next or where it will take you.

There are a small number of jumpscares throughout, but they are not over done and the ones that are in the game are done very well. There are quite a few horror clichés as well but are so well done you don't care how cheesy they are.
This game is absolutely crazy. Once you get into the locked room in the mansion (right at the start), that's when everything goes straight to hell.

Layers of Fear is a brilliant game and an absolute mindf*ck that plunges you into the mind of an artist who is rapidly descending into utter madness.

If you like horror, I highly recommend this game.

Early Access Review

A few glitches here and there and optimization issues.  For some reason selecting the quit to main menu option flashes between yes and no, making it difficult to leave the game. I'm not sure whether this was done on purpose.... Framerate drops are frequent when too many textures are present.

Beyond that, it was an immersive environment with pyschological horror aspects that gave a truly horrific feel (in a good way) that didn't rely too heavily on cheap jumpscares. The story is carefully drawn out in a chilling way, yet it keeps me wanting to come back.

A creative approach to the save system and collectables that didn't take away from the immersion.

Very positive experience, I felt it was worth the money for early access.

Early Access Review

For those viewing around late August, this game currently provides around 3 hours of play time, with more to come. If you played or watched PT and you enjoyed what you saw, this is must buy. This is definitely an experience that leaves most horror games in the dust. It makes you dread moving forward, yet the enviroment and events that occur make you scream 'I MUST EXPLORE'.

Most horror games succeed in making you feel stressed, tense using that as the overall emotion of the game. However, seeing this game described as 'psychedelic-horror' there is no truer title/genre than just that. While it may not provide the sense of urgency or peril as Amnesia or Alien: Isolation, this games atmosphere proves to be truly creepy and bizarre in a way that makes you wish it wouldn't end.

The 'Early Access' status typically stopped me from going further or even giving the game a chance. But I am so glad that I have taken a chance on this game because it seems so promising. If you are a fan of horror games, Layers Of Fear will surely surpass your expectations.

I never had such mixed feelings for a game before I played Layers of Fear. The first hour of it was absolutely exhilarating, props to the devs for absolutely nailing the bone-chilling atmosphere. Jump scares were minimal and the ever-changing layout of the protagonist's mansion helped alleviate the theme of insanity. I honestly regarded the game as one of the best horror games ever made, making even the likes of Amnesia pale in comparison.

Then, I got bored. The repetitiveness of the game did not bring out a sense of fear as it initially did, but instead brought out one of boredom. 2 hours in, and I didn't give a crap about the obviously painstakingly crafted environment, the changing layouts of the house and even the jump scares, and that wasn't all because of the repetitive nature of the game, about halfway through the game, there was a scene involving a ghost baby running into a drawer, how anyone found that to be even the least bit scary is beyond me. From then on, I failed to take the game seriously, the babyface" artwork that intentionally sent shivers down my spine for being disturbing soon descended to be nothing more than a funny face.

The thing which Outlast and Amnesia got right is that they never showed their hand too early on

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Where would i start....
Probably by saying that this is an early access game review.

Right, i think it's both fantastic and horrendous the way this game makes you feel. Honestly, i'm at the loss for words here.
The game itself looks brilliant, the atmosphere build up is absolutely gorgeous. It makes your jaw drop, and i find it interesting how much it makes enjoyable to feel fear and how much it plays with false sense of security. The story is intriguing, not many modern horror games can say that. I'm not going to compare this to any other game for a simple reason: This game is on a whole new level. It amazingly portrays the insanity, the mayhem in a deluded person's head. One must be open to interpretation. So far, i liked what i saw, this has a potential to become so much more, a trailblazer for modern horror games. Now, there are some elements that you might find it familiar, but i think, they were scrapped and unused in other projects, wasted potential, thus used in THIS game to it's full extent. I'm not gonna lie, i didn't know the weight of my decisions that i made, let me tell you one word - explore. Layers of Fear is one of the best horror games i played and it's still in early access. I want to commend the developers for such a game, you fellas have absolutely no shame, brilliant geniuses. At first i thought i'd list all the phobias that i encountered in the game, but honestly, the list would be too long. If you don't believe me, by all means, try this game out, and experience for yourself. I will update the review as the game develops.
The technical part of the game is stunning aswell. Graphics are beautiful and (terrible?) at the same time, the sfx and soundtrack are well suited and tuned. Everything in it's own accord, i did however experienced a slight drop in fps, at the very early part of the game, in a kitchen, at the left top corner, perhaps map rendering. Nothing too serious, because the game was like a finely tuned piano afterwards, for the rest of the playthrough. I really enjoyed this so far, and i'm looking forward to a full release. The best and worst experience you had in a  while.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok, so holy ♥♥♥♥ this game is good. I mean like really good suspense horror. It's got amazing amosphere, wonderful emersion, and attention to detail. This is what a horror game should be. It has just the right amount of jump scares that build up tense moments, and keep you wondering what is around the next door.  If you love intense story driven horror games, get this game! Like right now! Why are you reading this still!? Get this game.

Now for the cons. There are few besides it's short, 3 hours, but it's still EA. I hope to see at least another 5-10 hours added to this game. Tho I'm not sure how they could extend it out and keep it interesting. I have a feeling there is maybe 3 hours of story left for them to tell. But still good for a horror game. The other issue is frame rate. This game is graphiclly great looking. But I have a GTX980 and get sub 15 fps in some areas. For no reason. In the start of the game I was a solid 60 fps at 2160p. By the end of the game I was lucky to be at 30 fps at 1080p. This game needs a lot of optimizing for sure. For a EA game this is polished and looking great. Other issues are lack of audio in some areas. There is a room with a lot of floating objects, but they don't make a sound when you touch them. Things go flying all over the room and not a sound for them. There are also some bleed over issues from ajcent rooms. Playing on headphones as you should with this game, the sounds are to abrupt and break the imersion when they over lap in a odd way.

I also played this on TrinusVR with my phone, and it worked wonderfully. I was very happy with it in VR. This is the type of experience that VR is wonderful at. Now if my Nexus 4 only had a higher resolution screen. Running at sub 720p on the phone really takes away from the games beauty on my 4k monitor.

Bravo to the devs. This is the type of quailty EA game we need on steam. I look forward to the ending of this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For me this game is a true horror game gem, despite of it's simplicity as a game.
What you awaits is something I would actually call an advanced ghost train ride, it is linear (although the start makes a different impression), it has a simple story (yet not totally uninteresting) and it has simple gameplay (just very basic puzzles). But what is doing great is the horror and the graphics.

The high level of detail, the graphics style (that itself reminds of an painting) and the excellent sound and voice acting form astonishingly great atmosphere. The jumpscares are ingenoious and effective enough (means mostly not too hard) while not using loud sounds as a cheap way to do so. The game keeps playing with your mind and surprises all the time with new ideas. The large amount of really good paintings and drawings are making this game to an true art project. Who does actually still need a art museum, when you can get such great stuff delivered directly to your home computer?

reviewText:
You do three things in this game:

1. Walk
2. Turn Lights on and Off
3. Pick Up Things that Tell You Things
4* Poop

And yet, this game is 100% absolutely worth playing.

Mechanically, the game performs magic tricks. Walk into a room through a door. Turn around. Now there's no door there. Turn around again. Now, the room's a different room. Turn around again, there's new writing on the wall behind you. These magic tricks are what make it fantastic to play on the surface.

The story is what will truly delight you. It's disturbing in a heart-breaking way. Sadness and trepidation are the two feelings that will consume you throughout. You're a painter who's insane. But, you're also the husband-half of a marriage that was truly Hell toward its end. I'm not talking about Ray-Donovan-style, My husband's an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥
date: my wife's a ♥♥♥♥♥" Hell. I'm talking about a state of marriage that closely approximates the Christian vision of Hell. This game's story is an extremely convincing portrayal of that kind of Hell.\n\nPlay it. Seriously."

reviewText:
Layers of Fear is essentially a walking simulator, albeit a very good one. The horror aspects are modeled very closely to the playable teaser from Hideo Kojima and Guillermo del Toro, otherwise known a PT, wherein your character is trapped in a house with a vengeful ghost, and your goal is make it through.

Graphically the game is beautiful, as long as your PC is up to snuff, everything is well detailed and pops with vibrance; from the general house itself, to the black, inky corruption that slowly engulfs the husband's sanity.

Jump-scares are the primary go-to for the game's horror element, and although they're often predictable, there were several times when things got quiet, and I honestly felt unnerved and tense.

The faults I find come from the controls, and the game's length. Similar to another series by Frictional Games, Layers of Fear attempts to use a grab and pull mechanic, where you click an object, and then move your mouse in order to open doors, cabinets, and solve puzzles. Although I enjoy the control in general, It isn't as polished as Soma or Amnesia.

The other problem, and it's only a minor one, is the game's length. Even taking your time, you can finish it in a few hours. Depending on your preference, this may not be an issue, but personally, I like my games to be a little longer.

Those issues aside, I really enjoyed the game! It might be a walking simulator with a few puzzles, but Layers of fear is still worth your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PT meets Silent Hill 4: The Room, minus enemies, minus combat.

So, walking simulator then? I guess it starts that way...

This game is an absolute masterpiece of atmospheric terror and a great example of how to take primal fears and play them against the player. You don't need to be stalked by an enemy (ie Demento/Haunting Ground) for a large house to be scary. In fact you don't need anything LIVING in it, at all... (emphasis...).

I have never been so afraid of an empty house, ever... Yet at the same time compelled to keep going to unveil the truth. As you keep going, the game begins to feel more like SH4 in that the 'sanctuary' (for lack of any term...) being the art studio itself becomes more and more corrupted by evil. Yet its not a 'fantasy' evil, which is why this game is so horrendously frightening...

The story is one of madness, and an 'evil' borne of madness. It is not fantasy, it is all reality, and a very deep, dark disturbing look at exactly how low the human psyche can fall. It is an 'evil' that exists in the hearts of many, and because its something we can associate with, it simply makes the entire premise all the more frightening.

If having no combat makes this a walking simulator, then 10/10 would walk and ♥♥♥♥ my pants all over again.

I hate early access.

I hate the idea of paying for a game that isn't done, even if you're paying at a discount.

I also hate paying for short games, no matter how pretty the graphics are or 'infinite' replayability they have (roguelikes being an example).

But for some reason, I can't hate this game. I really tried to.

From the get go it nails on what I believe is the most important aspect of horror, which is atmosphere. I'm not going to romanticise it and say I felt 'dread,' because I didn't. I did feel like i did not want to progress, however, because it seemed that as I progressed, things just went to ♥♥♥♥ in worse ways.

I honestly became frustrated and uncomfortable when doors began disappearing and reappearing, exploiting impossibilities that are only possible when you're a limping man making your way thorugh your own home in a video game.

♥♥♥♥ early access. ♥♥♥♥ short games.

♥♥♥♥ this game... but in a good way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I strongly recommend this to any fan of horror! Despite being an early access, this game is honestly more functional than some fully released games. I managed to get through to the end of what has been made so far in about 2 hours and in that time I have experienced some truly spooky ♥♥♥♥. You can easily tell this game knows exactly what it wants to be and how it plans on achieving that. The atmosphere is chilling and sinister; lighting, sound and the amazing graphics truly make make this game stand out. The story telling is also very well realized through notes, items, interactions and even dialogue. A supernatural/physiological tour of haunted house with constant changing hallways and terrifying imagery. Some of the set pieces will most likely make you want to stop for a minute and just look around. Speaking of which, the imagery in this game is fantastic! Grotesque, insidious and beautifully horrific in the best of ways. I found myself taking screenshots of paintings, hallways and rooms covered in black liquid. So far this is the best horror game of 2015, I really like how insanely well realized and put together this game is.The game does use jump scares but often times I found it best when I was forced to go somewhere I desperately did not want to go, or was helpless to watch something creep towards me. The gameplay is somewhat minimal, walking around looking for what you can interact with(almost anything) and seeing if it has any use. Although the gameplay could be summarized as walking around and finding keys or the crazy sketches of a madman, I think walking simulator is a bit unfair but kind of true(I don't mind it but don't expect to be running from monsters and hiding under beds). Overall I think this game is well worth $10.

reviewText:
I will keep this spoiler free as much as possible.

So firstly the design of the game, the audio, its all fantastic aside from the jaggies that even 4xEQ supersampling + temporal aa wont remove.  The story is also compelling to a degree but i believe it starts to fall apart near the end which kinda ruins the entire game which is why I dont recommend buying it unless its around $10.

The game has some very obtuse mechanics that can be frustrating and they are not alluded to in game at all, you have to read guides to figure the stuff im talking about out for the most part.  The dev has been very active on the forums trying to explain this and that shouldnt be required.

The team did a stellar job getting the ball to the 5 yard line but they just couldnt cross the line which is heart breaking because i was really rooting for them.

Hopefully they make another game and take feedback into consideration because this team has major talent,

Now my complaints about some of the scares are minor.  I played with full 7.1 surround sound not headphones so audio cues worked well but even then i missed some scares and then other scares just fell flat.  It also seems like mid game they started running out of ideas on how to freak you out.  The game had almost no tension after the first 45 min which is a true shame.

I cant say I didnt enjoy alot of the title but I also cant say it met its potential which is why i say wait for a sale before you invest.  Its billed as the game PT could have been but thats just not true, not at all.

If you do buy it i suggest playing through once without help then for any further attempts you use a guide.  Sometimes I wish steam had a 3rd option instead of just yes and no because this game would fit that 3rd option.

reviewText:
I bought this game expecting something highly cerebral and spooky, but just about every design choice detracted from the overall experience:
The notice at the beginning of the game informed me that the experience would be a creation of the player, which changes according to the players choices, but over the course of the four hours I spent playing, I don't really recall making any choices. There are no puzzles to solve, just codes for safes and doors painted very plainly on the walls. Keys to pick and use in the very same room, for no reason than to briefly distract the player. Lots of drawers to open, but rarely anything worthwhile to find.
The notion I was sold on of exploring a constantly shifting Victorian mansion was also a letdown. The game takes advantage of the 'changing environment' trope to the point of vulgarity, and it becomes tiresome very quickly. After acquainting myself with the opening setting, everything is thrown out the window in favor of a very linear corridor-after-corridor approach, every door locked firmly behind you as you proceed. Expect to bump into reused assets through the entire game. It would have been much more effective to familiarise yourself with a set environment, and then maybe have it deteriorate/mutate halfway through the game.
The nature of the protagonists' quest is revealed through a series of hamfisted cluedropping, which left me saying 'get on with it!' for the rest of the game. The ending reveals what is at that time practically an open secret, and is very underwhelming.
The most cardinal sin here is the lack of any real danger to the player. There's a creature that shows up here and there, but evading it is as simple as going back the other way. You don't even have a reason to do that. After a brief spook, you get back on your feet and be on your merry way.  The absence of any kind of fail-state fails to induce any kind of creative or intuitive play on behalf of the player; You can go through doors and corridors right up to the end after every encounter with the creature.
The multiple endings seem to be built around the notion of returning to previous chapters to collect more things and evade the nasty, but just finishing the game once proved a real chore. I can't recommend this game for anyone but the thirstiest horror fan. A poor man's Amnesia.

Early Access Review

This game was fantastic, and considering this is only the early access review, I can only expect it to become even better. In a lot of ways, this game reminds me of the greatest horror game that never was, Silent Hills P.T.   If I had to liken it to another game on Steam, I would compare it to Anna. Very cerebral, non-traditional horror gaming.

It gives you a very disturbing insight into the mind of a troubled, creative genius. But the story isn't simply handed to you, you gradually piece it together as you wander a maze of a house decked out with 19th century style . This game does not rely on gore or jumpscares, but rather tries to get inside your head and mess with your perceptions and really make you feel that sense of madness and dread. You wander through a seemingly endless loop, and as you helplessly search room to room, you slowly realize the house has became an entity itself rather than just a setting; a living, breathing, evolving thing. I can't wait to see more!

reviewText:
Layers of fear is an exploration of a deteriorating mind of a once genius painter. He had (or maybe still has) a wife and a daughter, but his main focus is not the family, but his yet-to-be-completed best painting - his Magnum Opus. You delve deep into the everchanging coridors of an old mansion to finish the masterpiece and simultaneously uncover hints to the tragic story of this man's life.

The story itself is uncertain and open to speculation, since you never know the full picture, but the experience you get, while trying to salvage and put together the bits and pieces of whatever you're looking for, is truly a horror one. The studio uses a vast variety of methods to make you question every single item in each room, every single turn, door or window. The grotesque transformations deliver a unique (and overly original, compared to the other similar titles in the industry) feeling of dealing with the unknown.

I found the game frightening, disturbing, building tension and stress, with a fair dose of bizzare puzzles and a fistful of classic jumpscares in the sea of horror tropes. In my opinion this piece is an exquisite horror game and should be played by fans and newcomers of the genre alike, as it sets high standards for the titles to come. Plus it deserves a fancy-worded review, so here you go.

reviewText:
Horror games have always been a hit-or-miss for me. Jumpscares and less-than-stellar stories have ruined the genre for me, but Layers of Fear looked interesting and had good reviews. Merited at least me trying and, if it was terrible, returning.

Let me tell you how glad I am that I bought this. I purchased back when it was just released into Early Access and it was superb. There wasn't the full story or the full game, but there was enough to get me very interested.

For starters, let's talk about how it compares to other games in the genre. I recently played SOMA and found this one to be much better; while there was nothing literally hunting you down, there was still a sense of urgency when the wife is around. You know she isn't here to hug you. Layers of Fear also has better level design in the sense of not giving you real safe areas to backtrack to; for the most part, you enter a new room and you're stuck there until you progress.

The story is really good too. I was dreading to see how they'd end it but they definitely pulled it off.

I'd recommend the game. Definitely worth the money!

reviewText: A decent idea with a fantastic aesthetic, but Layers of Fear is less of a horror game and more of a haunted house simulator. reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is what horror fans have been waiting for for a while now. This game is no Amnesia clone like most horror games are nowadays, but something completely different. And it really works.

Instead of facing the traditional monsters, the danger is that you're trapped in your own mind. The game offers a very plausble view of what it would be like to be insane, and sooner or later you'll find that you accept all the impossible things that you witness. It's almost like a batshit simulator.

The game does use jump scares, a fair few even, but they're not actually meant to startle you, they're more there to keep you on the edge of your seat. The constantly shifting environment the player finds himself in is actually way more unsettling because you never know what's going to happen, anything at all is possible. The realisation that anything could happen at any time is what drives the suspense here, and it works brilliantly.

The way this all ties together is how in this game the environment can change when you're not looking. Drastically. As you can't see everything at the same time, you're always vulnerable to the things that are just outside the corner of your eye. Trying to keep things in your vision makes you inevitably turn your back on something else. Nowhere is safe, and that's what the game expertly impresses on you. Just like a truly insane person.

Another thing that has to be said is the visuals. The textures are razor sharp and the models are very nice. The best thing is the artwork in this game though. Who made all this? Even if you're not a fan of the gameplay, the paintings themselves are quite beautifully made. Expert work here.

Highly recommended for any fans of the horror genre. While still in development and not the scariest game I've ever played, it's definitely among the most elegant.

Early Access Review

My only complaint about this, is that it's not yet finished.  And I don't mean that the game has bugs that cripple it, that's to be expected with Early Access.  It's why I generally avoid them like the plague.

But, with that said...  I watched some videos, read some reviews and figured I'd give it a shot.  It's only a fiver atm after all right?

But no, the game is literally, not finished.  I got a part way through the fourth part (don't want to say anymore as I don't want to spoil it) and it just stopped and said 'Thanks for playing, hope you enjoy more later'.  I at least come to expect the main part of the story to be in the game when you're paying money for it!  So, to me, this is a major point of concern.  If the dev's now decide to say sod it, I'm never going to know the ending.  That, my friends, would be unforgivable.

But, with that said, I am going to risk giving this a thumbs up.  Why?  Because it's cheap.  I played near 3.5 hours investigating things and at times, my heart was pounding and I 'wanted' to know where the story was going.  I have my suspicions, as we all probably do, but I want to see it there, done and dusted right in front of me.  So, for this reason I would say it's worth a £5 one off payment.  Besides, it's only 90 minutes off my normal £1/hour preferred rate, so can't really complain there either.

Just keep in mind, there are some bugs (had a draw in the bedroom move into the chest-of-drawers itself when I moved) and the game isn't yet complete.  But if you're a fan of psychological horror that's not just 'run and hide until it goes away', definitely take a look.

reviewText:
DISCLAMER - Incase you didn't know, this is my opinion based on my experience in the game. You may not either agree with my opinion or have the same experience I had with my gameplay.

This is a long review so get comfortable.

So I bought this game, last year, the day after its early-access release. The full game came out, only a few days ago, and I have to say that I'm utterly amazed.

Since the full release, the developers have added far new content, completed the story (obviously), added scares and even improved scares. The story behind it, if you pay close attention, is fascinating and the ending (if you get what it means) is shocking.

The story - 8/10

Of course, this being a horror game, it does have scares (duh). However, most modern day horror games don't really put that much effort, imagination or skill into their scares, it's litterly just some thing that jumps at the screen and makes you wet yourself a little, but only scares you for that brief few seconds. Unlike these games, this little gem scares you in a different way. This game not only scares you, but completely ♥♥♥♥s with your mind, thanks to its unsettling music and creepy atmosphere. This game does use jumpscares, but uses them discreetly. It doesn't do it every few minutes or seconds like 'Five Nights at Freddy's'.

The scares - 10/10 (for being the most clever in-game scares I've ever come across)

Finally, there's the atmosphere. I was completely immersed in the atmosphere of this game. One of the things that helped with my immersion was there being no loading screens at all. The game 'Outlast' did this also, creating an immersive and realistic world. The visuals are one of the best I've seen in an Indie game, both textures and post-processing. The lighting was pretty-much accurate and the textures looked pretty. Of course there was the music. The music completely immersed me into the game, giving me the feeling that I shouldn't be there or something isn't right (well, it is a horror game of course).

Immersion/atmosphere - 9.5/10

I conclusion, if it wasn't obvious enough, I absolutely love this game. It uses great visuals, music, scares, atmosphere and story. Pretty much everything that makes a good horror game.

So, my final rating for the game has to be - 9.7/10

The developers got almost everything right (but hey, no game is perfect). As much as this is my favorite horror game so far, they could have made the story a little more obvious to new players. When I first got the game last year, I was kind of clueless about the story when I first played it. After playing it another time, I started to get it, but I guess that's just me. Anyway, I think Bloober Team did an amazing job with this game and I hope to see more games from them in the future.

If you have a spare fifteen quid in your wallet, I reccommend that you definetly give this a try in your spare time, preferably at night (for immersion of course).
