reviewText:
Incredible horror experience :D Loved every minute of it! I've been playing this game since it went on Early Access and have now played the full version beginning to end.


GRAPHICS

Absolutely superb. Brilliant use of lighting and shadows. Simply put some of the best interior graphics I've seen, perhaps only beaten by the legendary P.T.

However playing with a triple screen set up (5760x1080) isn't perfect. For one getting close to walls with 3 screens causes the camera but not the player to clip through. This does not happen with traditional resolutions.

Also with 3 screens microstuttering is a serious issue and the game can't hit 60 FPS (Intel Core i7 4790K, GTX 980 Ti, 8 GB RAM). It hovers in the 45-50 FPS range but feels like 15 because of the stuttering. Again, not at all an issue at normal resolutions. Microstuttering remains an issue in the full release as well even at 1920x1080.


SOUND

Mostly good, very rarely rather bad, often exceptional but honestly 95% of the time it's just generic horror game type sounds. Lots of sudden loud sounds used for jump scares. However there are maybe 4 or 5 sound effects that really sounded bad to me. Fortunately they're quick and non-looping sounds. The music is exceptional and sets the mood brilliantly. They actually do some really cool stuff with music in the game.


CONTROLS

They do the job well but are a bit erratic. You'll be looking around steadily then suddenly it accelerates really fast. It's really not that bad but these are not CoD or Halo controls. Also it's not uncommon to get stuck on small objects.


SCARES

A nearly even mix of psychological and jump scares... and man are there a LOT of both! This isn't your traditional horror game where you'll have to wait an hour or two for the scares to start. It's pretty much right off the bat with Layers of Fear. There's plenty of really messed up imagry that works REALLY well. There's also a lot of jump scares that are surprisingly well crafted given how common they are in this game. Even at the very end the jumps feel fresh and unexpected.

Regrattably I don't get that sense of dread I get with games like P.T. and Amnesia. Layers of Fear is more like a very colorful and really bad acid trip. Also, while creepy (monster spoilers ahead) the ghost feels like a direct copy and paste of Lisa from P.T. in both the way she looks and moves and in the way she kills you but with naked boobies (I seem to recall reading that this was deliberate but I'm not sure)

One problem that I had with the game prerelease was that the scares were just packed WAY too close together. This has been mostly fixed but not completely. Particularly towards the end it feels like the scares are happening one right after the other diminishing the effect.


GAMEPLAY

There really isn't any. There are some relatively simple yet clever puzzles and a few scavenger hunts but that's it. There's no combat, no hiding, no inventory ect. This game is definitely a walking simulator" but damn is it a good one!


STORY

Decent. It's told almost completely through hidden and optional newspaper clippings and notes so what you get out of the story depends on how much you like to explore and read. If you DO take your time and look around I thought the characters were very interesting. The story isn't going to blow you away but I did find that I wanted to know what happened and the story definitely added to the messed up mood the game is going for.


REPLAY VALUE

Limited however this game is just PACKED with detail. Even more detail than P.T. It's the type of game where you will definitely notice something different each time you play. I played through each of the prerelease versions multiple times and it always felt fresh even though it was the same. And with the full release they've added a TON more content. There's also quite a bit of notes
date:
newspaper clippings and drawings to find.


WHO IS THIS GAME FOR?

For: P.T

reviewText:
DISCLAMER - Incase you didn't know, this is my opinion based on my experience in the game. You may not either agree with my opinion or have the same experience I had with my gameplay.

This is a long review so get comfortable.

So I bought this game, last year, the day after its early-access release. The full game came out, only a few days ago, and I have to say that I'm utterly amazed.

Since the full release, the developers have added far new content, completed the story (obviously), added scares and even improved scares. The story behind it, if you pay close attention, is fascinating and the ending (if you get what it means) is shocking.

The story - 8/10

Of course, this being a horror game, it does have scares (duh). However, most modern day horror games don't really put that much effort, imagination or skill into their scares, it's litterly just some thing that jumps at the screen and makes you wet yourself a little, but only scares you for that brief few seconds. Unlike these games, this little gem scares you in a different way. This game not only scares you, but completely ♥♥♥♥s with your mind, thanks to its unsettling music and creepy atmosphere. This game does use jumpscares, but uses them discreetly. It doesn't do it every few minutes or seconds like 'Five Nights at Freddy's'.

The scares - 10/10 (for being the most clever in-game scares I've ever come across)

Finally, there's the atmosphere. I was completely immersed in the atmosphere of this game. One of the things that helped with my immersion was there being no loading screens at all. The game 'Outlast' did this also, creating an immersive and realistic world. The visuals are one of the best I've seen in an Indie game, both textures and post-processing. The lighting was pretty-much accurate and the textures looked pretty. Of course there was the music. The music completely immersed me into the game, giving me the feeling that I shouldn't be there or something isn't right (well, it is a horror game of course).

Immersion/atmosphere - 9.5/10

I conclusion, if it wasn't obvious enough, I absolutely love this game. It uses great visuals, music, scares, atmosphere and story. Pretty much everything that makes a good horror game.

So, my final rating for the game has to be - 9.7/10

The developers got almost everything right (but hey, no game is perfect). As much as this is my favorite horror game so far, they could have made the story a little more obvious to new players. When I first got the game last year, I was kind of clueless about the story when I first played it. After playing it another time, I started to get it, but I guess that's just me. Anyway, I think Bloober Team did an amazing job with this game and I hope to see more games from them in the future.

If you have a spare fifteen quid in your wallet, I reccommend that you definetly give this a try in your spare time, preferably at night (for immersion of course).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a fan of horror games, this has to be one of the best ones I've played.  The detail in the environment is top notch and the graphics are great.  Despite the haunting environment, the mansion is beautiful.  One thing I like is the area changes as you walk through the house (think of the Stanley Parable).  Sometimes just turning around will change the room!  They did a great job with the environment changes and jump scares.  Because the doors and hallways change and the jump scares are so surprising it adds to the scare factor and makes the game less predictable.  From what I've gathered, I think you're seeing stuff through the eyes of a crazy artist and/or the house is haunted.  Either way it's scary!

Pros
Great horror game.
Simple controls.
Unpredictable - changing environment.
Graphics and detail.
Voice acting.
You can explore - cabinets, drawers, find items, etc.
Storyline - there isn't a huge story to this but just enough to make it interesting.  Find clues in the house.

Cons
None.

reviewText:
I love this game! Was planning to wait, sleep, and stream it later today. But heck - once I tested out the opening scene I had to finish it.

Ends out the story is rather complex and requires the pieces to fit in order to fully understand. Without giving away too much spoiler - I'd assume the game is a run down of the mental anguish the artist endures with each painting. Even if he captures a lost beauty in each painting he can not recreate anything as good as what he lost. Given what I found at the end in the kitchen, and the letter in the desk of the office, along with the items you collect throughout the game trying to recreate that beauty lost to a perfection. I assume he needed a sample of the original to attempt painting it from more than just memory.

The story reminds me of Exmortis. Graphics similar to Silent Hill. Jump scares of Dead Space 2. And some scenes either FEAR 2 or Among the Sleep.

Either way - This is the long awaited game I desired ever since Slender New Arrival was too short and easily completed with minimal effort. Great job overall. Left the story do be decided by the player based around clues uncovered along the way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Dear, Steam.
Layers of Fear is a pc exclusive horror game and holy f***ing s**t is it scary.
Sadly it runs on unity engine (An unfortunately basic game engine)
It was released on the 8/27/15 (The day of writing this)
The game does need some tweaking e.g no windowed mode, lack of options.
AND HOLY F***ING S**T IS IT BEAUTIFUL!
But if you take time to look around you will see a lot of low poly models and they feel out of place due to the fact that they are so close to high quality, high poly models. I myself crashed 4 times trying to boot it up but after tweaking it works flawlessly.

The game is absolutely drenched in atmospheric horror that is similar to games like Amnesia and P.T.  During the parts I played (even with my friend making jokes with me) we still were absolutely terrified without even the tiniest of jumpscares. The game genuinely makes you terrified by going up the stairs. Let me repeat this, the game makes you scared about GOING UP THE STAIRS. I only played 44 minutes of it in total and I was still absolutely terrified. The game’s added beautiful graphics adds a more realistic level of fear as well, you really feel like you are this person roaming the halls of this abandoned house. In short, I was wonderfully immersed in one of the best horror games in a while.

Thanks to John Turner (TheBrokenKeyboard) for helping me survive this game and this review

Then, everything becomes disconnected. Spacial relationships become irrelevent, as you walk repeatedly down similar corridors. The game feels like it's been fleshed out through asset repetition: Walk down the brown hallway -> Brown Door Locked -> Walk back the way you came to enter new but strikingly similar brown hallway.

reviewText:
Layers of Fear may, at first glance, seem like another stock standard first person horror game but it surprised me in a lot of ways, in the sense that it made me sh*t a hole straight through my chair.
The game does a very good job of putting together a very surreal and unnerving atmosphere, with all the paintings of various nutters staring at you from the walls, and the lighting effects and amazing sound design do an even better job.
It really frightened me and though it's not without jumpscares, the atmosphere does enough on its own to keep your hand clenched on the mouse as if it's magnetised.
However, the game is not without its flaws - it can get somewhat repetitive and one or two scares come across as a bit tired, but for all that it's a fantastic horror game I strongly believe you should add to your library
Just make sure you're wearing extra thick pants

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine taking all the elements of a really good horror film, sans blood and gore, have it directed by Guillermo Del Toro, make it into an interactive game and that's what you have here.

Layers of Fear is fantastic; tons of atmosphere, great visuals and audio to match and simplistic gameplay with light puzzle elements to keep you involved. The house feels very lived in and believable, the narrative is presented wonderfully, and the audio will leave you wondering What the hell is making that sound?" The game left me feeling like the idiotic lead in many a horror film that constantly walks towards danger in order to feed their curiousity only to find themselves scared and feeling vulnerable.

It's the perfect haunted house game and if you're looking for some good scares you won't go wrong with Layers of Fear."

Early Access Review

I haven't really played much of this game, (2.0 hrs) [as steam states], but in two hours I have experienced something quite unique and very horrifying.

Unique might be stretching it a bit but the ingenuity of the game’s motive and storyline (or lack thereof) can create an eerie feeling. On-edge and tense were the only emotions I felt while playing it, and the tension keeps building and then, at that moment, your most vulnerable state, is when the game strikes. There is a stage where I just can't get past because, well, I’m genuinely scared and couldn't stop looking behind my chair to see if there's something or someone there. Not many games ever make me feel this scared, and when the jump scares come, every part of your body is stimulated and a shock is induced through your core that leaves you f**ked up.

Atmospheric, enjoyable, horrifying, tense and genuinely intelligent this game pieces together emotions and recreates classic works of art and mixes generically clever horror to craft an entirely new perspective… one we may never have thought the artists or ourselves might’ve had.

If you’re an adrenaline junky; put your headphones on, turn off the lights and mentally prepare yourself to literally crap your pants and sob like a little bi**h.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am old and jaded and find things like car payments and health insurance premiums scarier than most horror games nowadays. Despite this, Layers of Fear did a fantastic job of genuinely creeping me out. It has 1 or 2 jump scares you can see coming from a mile away but honestly the main attraction here is the fantastic attention to atmosphere, which is arguably the most important aspect of a truly scary horror game.

The game is very subdued and subtle at first but as the game progresses it becomes more and more unhinged, the environments and atmosphere transitioning from unnerving to outright disturbing. This game is very passive" and you spend most of your time walking around looking at things  but it does a fantastic job of keeping you on your toes and wondering what's coming next.

If you've played Silent Hill games you're definitely going to notice the subtle homages here and there. I caught quite a few references to SH4 and at least one for SH2...

Overall I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a horror game that focuses less on monsters jumping out of closets and more on making you dread what's around the next corner
date: \n\nNow for some criticism: The game feels a bit too predictable and linear in its current state. After playing it through once I really don't have much incentive to do it again because I already know everything that's going to happen and the order in which it happens. That's not a problem right now since it's just an early access game
recommended: but in the full version it would be great if it were more unpredictable or if it were possible to do things in a different order."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I greatly enjoy this type of psychological horror game. Although it's not 100% complete I'd say it's right on track with the early Silent Hill games, Amnesia, Penumbra, and the like.

Good:
-Graphics, art design, visual effects, and use of sound are all outstanding.
-The game does a terrific job of focusing your attention on certain things and using that to scare you.
-Perhaps the game's greatest strength is how seamless the room transitions are. I won't spoil any more than that.
-Very happy that this game was created using Unity, an amazing free to use engine.
-Amazing that just about all of the creepy artworks are from real life.
-An interesting narrative that will hopefully have a twist or a revelation in the end, it doesn't overwhelm the player with too much info so that's good too.

Bad:
-It's still early access, so it's not done. I played through it in about 2 hours.
-My fairly new computer was pushed to the limit on this one, there might be some optimization issues that still need to be addressed. The framerate was somewhat choppy throughout but not so bad that I couldn't enjoy it or stream it for others.

If you have any interest in scaring yourself or others I highly recommend that you buy the Early Access version of the game to support the developers, turn the lights off and prepare to soil yourself. It's a lot of fun.

Incredibily unpredictable and intriguing horror game. Even though this is in early alpha, the flaws barely hinder the gameplay and atmosphere of this amazing experience. I was playing with a friend, and after every critical event, we would agree on how incredible this game is.

The game has a great pace. You  always wonder what is around the corner as it constantly puts you into new enviroments. There is a great blend of lore and horror as you wonder which belongs in each room. You'll find that the lore keeps you intrigued enough to continue into even the most obvious of bad decisions.

PT has been related to this game and I'm not suprised. The scenery and atmosphere is similar, but the lore is much more potent in Layers of Fear. Lets not forget that PT was a demo to a game that is now cancelled and so this is now the best shot at a full experience to what Silent Hills" could have offered. This is potentially a one of a kind title that could change the way horror games are experienced and approached for a long time."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Borrows heavily from the Silent Hill PT.

This is a very short game that is a lot like the Playable Trailer of Silent Hill.  This is not a bad thing, I personally loved the trailer and love the direction of this game.  As of right now this game is not finished quite finished (or I must have done something really wrong) but it is still only Early Access at the moment so don't be dissapointed at its super quick ending.
This game does a wonderful job at molding an atmosphere for a horror game, albeit quite a few of the scares were extremely predictable.  Which most horror is to begin with so its a meh thing to me.  Also this may be simply because it is still Early Access but the movement is slight yanky and doesn't feel very fluid, too many times it would take quite a bit of time to just get my guy to face a drawer just right to open it.  Some of the rooms are very well done, (Baby room was probably my favorite) and yet some felt really bland (Room with 3 Paintings.)

Also *Spoiler?* the Zombie/Ghost/Woman attacks were way too predictable every time, and the animation felt like it was rather forced (I feel like its probably because it seemed to drag on longer than what was necessary) and is the exact same animation sequence every time. *Spoiler End*

All in all a fantastic horror that is going in a fantastic direction, and in my opinion how a horror game should be, it succeeds in creating a beautiful atmosphere that has the potential to send chills down your spine.  However a game that does have such limited actual gameplay more attention should be put into the details of this beautiful work of art to really make it shine.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game does a fantastic job of creating atmosphere and telling the story without spoon-feeding it to the player. The artwork chosen works beautifully with the setting and story, and the music creates a beautifully sorrowful ambiance, with the exception of one odd adddition that conflicts with the rest of the soundtrack. However, while the level design and attention to detail create the feeling of life and history in the house, the dialogue and voice acting fall a bit flat, leading to an inconsistent character rather than a complex one. This issue tends to leave the story a bit confused, uncertain of what kind it wants to be. Despite this, the story was still interesting and I'm looking forward to the playing through the finished product. As a horror game, Layers of Fear wasn't quite as scary as its title would merit, but it is an interesting experience nonetheless, and is worth playing, especially for fans of gothic horror.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am old and jaded and find things like car payments and health insurance premiums scarier than most horror games nowadays. Despite this, Layers of Fear did a fantastic job of genuinely creeping me out. It has 1 or 2 jump scares you can see coming from a mile away but honestly the main attraction here is the fantastic attention to atmosphere, which is arguably the most important aspect of a truly scary horror game.

The game is very subdued and subtle at first but as the game progresses it becomes more and more unhinged, the environments and atmosphere transitioning from unnerving to outright disturbing. This game is very passive" and you spend most of your time walking around looking at things  but it does a fantastic job of keeping you on your toes and wondering what's coming next.

If you've played Silent Hill games you're definitely going to notice the subtle homages here and there. I caught quite a few references to SH4 and at least one for SH2...

Overall I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a horror game that focuses less on monsters jumping out of closets and more on making you dread what's around the next corner
date: \n\nNow for some criticism: The game feels a bit too predictable and linear in its current state. After playing it through once I really don't have much incentive to do it again because I already know everything that's going to happen and the order in which it happens. That's not a problem right now since it's just an early access game
recommended: but in the full version it would be great if it were more unpredictable or if it were possible to do things in a different order."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I greatly enjoy this type of psychological horror game. Although it's not 100% complete I'd say it's right on track with the early Silent Hill games, Amnesia, Penumbra, and the like.

Good:
-Graphics, art design, visual effects, and use of sound are all outstanding.
-The game does a terrific job of focusing your attention on certain things and using that to scare you.
-Perhaps the game's greatest strength is how seamless the room transitions are. I won't spoil any more than that.
-Very happy that this game was created using Unity, an amazing free to use engine.
-Amazing that just about all of the creepy artworks are from real life.
-An interesting narrative that will hopefully have a twist or a revelation in the end, it doesn't overwhelm the player with too much info so that's good too.

Bad:
-It's still early access, so it's not done. I played through it in about 2 hours.
-My fairly new computer was pushed to the limit on this one, there might be some optimization issues that still need to be addressed. The framerate was somewhat choppy throughout but not so bad that I couldn't enjoy it or stream it for others.

If you have any interest in scaring yourself or others I highly recommend that you buy the Early Access version of the game to support the developers, turn the lights off and prepare to soil yourself. It's a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a walking simulator, but while I was dissapointed with the Stanley Parable the only other walking simulater I have played, this one is actually really good. It looks good. The story is great. The atmosphere is phenomenal. I was really anxious at some parts because the game is so unpredictable and innovative. It uses level shifting in a really great way.
The horror elements are perfect. Due to the overall pacing of the game an immersive atmosphere is uphold throughout the playable story. Unlike games that pretend to be horror games, but only overwhelm you with massive amounts of splatter and gore, the Layers of Fear uses subtle methods instead to create psycholigical horror. While there are many jump scares thorughout the game, the actual story which unfolds itself through collectibles has a significant impact on the way you perceive the actual game world and contributes greatly on the lasting impact this game has on your mind.

While the actual game itself is short, I cant complain much for this relative low price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought Layers of Fear after seeing it get some pretty good feedback and I was absolutely not disappointed. Graphically good-looking, atmospheric, subtle and effective, this Early Access game already feels like a full game. Every event is a pleasant (and at times unpleasant) surprise. There's something new behind every door you open and it constantly keeps you on your toes. The game doesn't drag things out and it's not filled with jumpscares - it's trying to tell a story and you'll find yourself wanting to get to the end so you can figure out what happened.

Layers of Fear reminds me and makes me miss the Silent Hill's P.T. demo. In many respects it feels like what P.T. could have been and that in itself is an amazing thing. I can guarantee you you will get your money's worth here. Now, grab it and go play it!

reviewText: One of the purest horror games I've played in a long time. I believe the scariest kind of horror is psychological. Monsters, zombies, serial killers and the like are all well and good, but they’re transient fears. If you kill them, distract them, hide from them, they go away. Psychological fear and trauma however, never go away. They exist inside the player and the lead character, and follow them everywhere they go, growing stronger and more potent as you fall deeper into the rabbit hole of madness. It doesn’t make you fear for your life, but for your sanity. Luring you into the foreboding sense that they you are in fact losing your own mind. As the line between fantasy and reality blurs further and further the more the game progresses. And while that kind of horror is not for everyone. It is for me. And if it is for you this game is a must play

reviewText:
Sometimes it's refreshing to play a game about something other than wholesale combat. Take Layers of Fear, for instance, a game in which you get to explore the mind of an artist, as he dwells in his solitude and ponders his magnum opus.

...Sure, he's deranged....and he may be a serial killer, haunted by the spirit of his deformed dead wife and child....but ART, man!

Layers of Fear is one of those new wave indie games found frequently on Steam or in Humble Bundle deals (I snagged mine at Green Man Gaming for a nice discount on a Steam key copy). It's not about shooting stuff, or even about a coherent story, necessarily. Instead, it's about an experience.

On the Venn Diagrams of roller-coaster rides" and "Deep psychological horror experiences" you'll find Layers of Fear smack in the center
date: offering an experience in which you make your way through the visions of a man either deranged or tormented (or both) in a surreal depiction of what is either a grotesque personal haunting
hoursPlayed: or something more profane (such as a personal purgatory made real).\n\nThe story is told in bits and pieces as you advance
voteText: each piece suggesting the bigger picture at work. Occasionally you will run into vaguely challenging puzzle bits
helpfulPercent: but nothing remotely weird or unusual; this is not a puzzle game
votesHelpful: and what "puzzles" you find are ultimately part of the overall process of moving the experience forward. The longest roadblock I ran in to took about three minutes to figure out
votesTotal: for example...and only because I wasn't looking for something obvious.\n\nOne thing which kept coming to my mind while playing....and if you play
votesFunny: you'll see why....was a vague sense that there was more than a little inspiration from Lovecraft's Rats in the Wall sand Pickman's Model. There's no explicit narrative connection
commentsCount: but the thematics

column17: and occasional...ah....rat will have you suspecting that that Layers of Fear is in the same ballpark as these tales.\n\nAnother reason to enjoy Layers of Fear: it has some geuine

reviewText:
Finally, a narrative experience that utilises player identification and perspective to narrate a story through the medium of gaming itself! 'Layers of Fear' draws on art history, Lovecraft, Poe and others, synthesising them into a psychological exploration of an artist's fractured mind as he attempts to work through the loss of his family.

In terms of mood and mechanics, it feels somewhat like what I saw of the 'Silent Hills' demo; you explore and interact with the environment to move the story forward: the way you interact with the world will affect how things unfold. It falls somewhere between the uninteractive walking simulator and a full adventure game. However, the game's relative lack of mechanics never bothered me, as the art and sound design, the narrative, the environments, the use of visual effects to suggest feelings/mental state are all absolutely brilliant and compelling in their own right.

This is one of the very few games that have ever delivered on the promise of telling a story effectively through a game engine, while also using game mechanics effeciently and intelligently to enhance its storytelling. I look forward to seeing whatever this studio comes up with next.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although short in gameplay (I knocked out the game in about 112 minutes), this game will definitely creep you out. I love the whole changing rooms idea (Very similar to P.T. when it was still available on PSN). However, unlike P.T., you're not going through the same hallway over and over and over again. It's an entire victorian era manor (in I believe the 1960's) you get to explore. Every door you open is a new surprise.

The atmosphere in this game is incredible. The devs took ideas from Amnesia and P.T. and combined them to make a potential masterpiece. Everything from the sound, lighting, and artwork will give you the chills as you explore your own home (or is it?).  The story is something I found very interesting. I found myself wanting to know more about  the background of the main protagonist, the relationship with his wife and daughter, and why he resorted to violent outbursts and alcoholism... Did he kill his wife and use her body to create art? I MUST KNOW MORE!. The pace is also similar to P.T. You aren't really running from anything, so you can't sprint... Plus you're character appears to have a prosthetic leg of some sort, so you can feel your character kind of limp while walking (you can feel it through hearing the footstep and thud... Really well done sound).

Now for the psychological horror part. I love how they incorporated artwork into generating fear. Am I the only one who finds older portraits creepy? There's one scene in the game, near the beginning, where you fall into the basement into complete darkness. After stumbling around a bit, I managed to find the lightswitch, turn it on, turn around... and BAM! There was this really big, creepy portrait just staring at me, lol. There are some jumpscares... But nothing as cheap as the FNAF series. The use of artwork portraying the protagonist's obvious battle with creator's block and apparent schizophrenia is beyond awesome.

Now... There were some blatant issues... The caption text when compared what's actually written on the object/note does have some grammatical/spelling/mismatch errors.  I did notice on one moment where  the apparent wife" grabs you and breaks your neck and causes you to pass out  the camera did the look around animation prior actually waking up... Causing you to get a better look at  said "wife". This didn't feel like it was part of the game.

In it's current state
date: Layers of Fear has some extreme potential to be among the most recommended psychological horror game for the Halloween season; up there with Amnesia

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay, so where do I start? Where do we all start, for that matter?

Of course, for a story like this, we need to start at the beginning.

So we start off on a journey of pulling yourself back on your feet, as an artist who has fallen from grace in the circles he hanged out in. I'll spare you the story side, aside from the part where the reason why he fell from grace is because he went insane.

Still not offering anything new to the table so far, I'll get to the point. The great thing about this game is the execution of the premise. This game works on the same levels of Silent Hill, where layers of reality are peeled off into something otherworldy. Unlike Silent Hill, however, you don't have monsters to fight along the way to reach your goal. But a game of this genre is not in the monsters you fight; it's in the monsters of the mind, the inner demons. Or, in other words, the tragic pieces of the puzzle that make up the character's background, and that that as the player, you pick up along the way.

An artist sees the world in a different way than regular people, or so it is said. But just how differently can someone see the world, if you're insane? Reality's all a matter of perception, and in this game, it peels off like some poor-quality painting, a clear indication of how frail the protagonist's mind is.

Although still in development at the time I write this review, the game promises some considerable jumps right out of the chair. The daunting atmosphere can be felt from minute one, and the exploration will not allow you to miss one second of it; so all you faint of heart beware, for you will be put to the test, as the growing sense of unease settles in progressively.

reviewText:
Honestly for an early access game this was VERY impressive. Unlike most horror games where you can have a relative idea of what's going to happen to you, in this game you truly never know what's going to happen. Literally doing something as simple as turning around or opening a random door can change everything. Also the game has like a crescendo kind of effect and flow where right when you thought things couldn't get any worse, they do but in a good way. The unnerving atmosphere, the sheer seamlessness of transitions in scares and environment, the gorgeous graphics, the story, everything in the game makes up for the fact that it is short. Keep in mind once again that this game is early access and they even mention in game that the game isn't finished yet. Personally I felt the game was totally worth the money I payed and was a fun way to get worked up for the Halloween season! I look forward to when they release more content.

~UPDATE 2/17/2016~

So I beat the game now that it fully released and the game did not disappoint! It's simple if you think about it but it works well for itself. They even added some new stuff to the beginning parts to give us something new to jump at lol.  I won't give any spoilers but just so you know: the game has multiple endings so it's worth replaying once or twice.

reviewText: Layers of Fear is a psychedelic horror game relying mostly on atmospheric and sanity tension than the usual jump-scares and loud sound screaming (although the game does contain a few as well). You are a painter who drives himself into deep madness. Everything seems to be executed very well, and the game is nicely polished ever since its previous versions. I am actually impressed how much the full release of the game has changed. Many of the areas have been changed to more proper places, whereas before, they made no sense at all. Voice acting seems to be pretty solid as well, and absolutely nothing wrong with it. The game could take you about 4-5 hours to complete, maybe less if you're not the explorer type, so it does render the game quite a bit short. However, the short journey you go through will drive you into insanity and fear, literally into layers of fear. I am also impressed with the level of detail the developers have created. The level-changing never fails to surprise, and it is perfectly executed as well.\n\nAt its price, the game offers a terrifying and unforgettable journey, making up for its lack of replayability and linear game-play. Either way, this is a great start for the team, and looking forward to more of their work in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Potential.


I've said it before in all the positive recommendations that I wrote. Never have I given a negative recommendation to a game, for I know only few such games. This game may be Early Acces and I damn hope it gets a standing ovation when it will be finished. But let's not change the subject, we're here to praise  Layers of Fear.

A game with high tier graphical output and expressive horror events that revolve around the death(?) of the protagonist's wife and the disappearence of their sole child which drove our poor man into insanity. In this game, insanity warps the labyrinthian home filled with the paintings of the artist into hideous and frightening mockeries of their original intent. Often to the point where one starts to wonder where does a weak perception of reality end and supernatural events start.

A great theme and setting with an ongoing plot that is currently still being readjusted. A GOTY of the year in the becoming right?

No.

I will say this before it's too late. I will replay this game as it is endlessly, buy steam keys for my family, dog, former lovers and favourite butcher shop in the neighbourhood. But only IF the end version of the game won't be centered around me wandering aimlessly in an endless dark house, already mad, from room to room as if I'm shopping for furniture.

No, many games did that in the past and I want Layer of Fear to be THE horror game that has a sense of progression similar to an operatic performance. A progression of those surreal jumpscares with highs and lows, trepidation and flow that make it more than ROOM 1 Jumpscare> ROOM 2 Jumpscare< HALLWAY Jumpscare 1 and make a glorious end to the plot from which we already received a few hints in our Early Acces experience.

Maybe I'm asking too much, and that is certainly true since you ALREADY have our money. So, why work hard for your future customers anyway?

reviewText: A must play with headphones because of the amazing sound design that is implemented in surround sound headphones and even the developers recommend it when you open up the game. The first 30 minutes of the game were very scary and I legit thought it was the scariest game I ever played.  I was playing on full volume and when the first scares started happening I was jumping constantly because I didn’t know what I was getting myself into and they felt unpredictable. However the game started being less scary the more I played because that shock factor had gone. There are jumpscares every single minute to the point where I became immune to them. The game then ended up being just a barrage of loud noises coming from your headphones which is such a shame because the creativity, scary imagery and atmosphere is all there but it wasn’t paced well at all because it was happening constantly. If they made the game twice the length and put the scares once every say 3-5 minutes that scare factor that I was experiencing at the start would have went on the entire time but because it was happening constantly without a rest I couldn’t feel anything from them. The fact that there are no stakes and you can't die doesn't help the game either. It’s such a shame because the level of creativity and imagination in this game is amazing it’s just the pacing of the scares that hold it back.  I can still easily recommend it because of the creativity and scary imagery alone and I am glad that I experienced the game.\n7/10 (Good)

reviewText:
Before everything, it's not worth the original price, 2.5 hours for 20€ is a joke, I mean that 2,5 hours is at least packed with content, but still. BUY THIS ONLY ON A MINIMUM 50% SALE.

So the thing why this game is better your average psychological horror/walking simulator is not because the psychology itself, rather the way it shows it. It's not scary and it's barely a game, but in exchange you get great symbolism and gorgeous art style, that's the least from a game having art as the main subject. The themes are dark and personal, although we can't be entirely sure what exactly happened, but that probably adds to the game. Why? Because we know one thing for sure: the character we control is a maniac and has basically zero sense of reality, I doubt he knows exactly what he had done, therefore we don't know either.

What sucks is that it's a walking simulator and it's ridiculously short. It wasn't an overwhelming experience, but it was a good one. I'd just be glad if developers making psychological horrors stopped making their games this short. It's not artsy or anything to not leave room for character development. It's just not complete, just for example look at Silent Hill 2 or Cat Lady, those games are longer, therefore they can show more, more character development (can) brings more symphathy for the characters, more complexity and depth. Just because you fill your game with notes, even if they are interesting, it won't bring the same satisfaction.

So, I don't know. I liked it, but if not on sale, I can't recommend. Objectively it's a good game, so whatever.

reviewText:
I'd give this game a 10/10. Honestly I've played quite the bit of horror games, from Resident Evil, which may or may not be considered a horror experience as of so far, all the way to SOMA and Amnesia: Dark Descent and Machine for Pigs. The amount of horror you get from games like that don't always appear genuine. In fact, while playing Amnesia, I don't think I got the feels I did from a game like Layers of Fear.

This game seduces me into the story. While I'm looking at notes and hunting rat pictures, I end up turning around to find that what I thought would be behind me was actually not there, instead a wonderful jump scare or two would greet me. That was wonderful, but when you think about that it seems like the jump scares would quickly get to be stale. Wrong. They end up getting creative with things and set up scares where you'd never expect them, and then switch right back to where you would expect them.

Developers of Layers of Fear knew exactly what kind of community they were trying to hit. Those who enjoy story and those who enjoy horror. They definately matched what they were going for. And this is coming from someone who had never heard of the game before I found it on Steam.

Again 10/10. I will most likely be playing this over and over again just to delve farther into the very pleasing story and horror environment. Well done.

reviewText:
Ever wonder how it feels like being seriously mentally ill? Schizophrenic? Delirious? Combined with heavy alcoholism, hallucinating the hell out of this world? Not knowing where you are? whether what you see is real? Are you remembering or experiencing the present? Whether you are dwelling in one of the dark corners of your desillusioned broken brain? Are you dead?

This game is what nightmares are made of. Beautiful, crippling, disturbing, hellish, tragic nightmares. I understand that these descriptions may make the game sound chaotic and without sense, but it's really well made, consistent and a true gaming experience that no other form of medium could deliver.

Layers of Fear is incredibly smart. I want to praise the developers for following their ideas to the end and doing something different. The game is really beautiful, the dark ambience soundtrack is one hell of a mood setter, the effects and physics are also truly convincing (especially when things stop behaving as they should).

My advice is to play this game slowly, when it's dark and with headphones. Observe your surroundings. Listen to the sounds. Ingest every location. Don't rush it. Turn slowly. And when you find a god-damn writing on the wall that says don't look back"
recommended: don't look back. And the last tip: don't play this before you go to sleep. Also avoid mirrors and paintings in real life for at least 1 hour.\n\nDon't look back."

reviewText:
So, I loved this game. Keep that in mind while I review it, because I'm going to say some things that might seem negative. Layers of Fear is a wholly atmospheric game with very little in the way of gameplay, a 'haunted house simulator' along the vein of Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs. Very much inspired by P.T., it uses its environment to scare and unnerve you instead of relying on jump scares or forced stealth gameplay. The story is quite obvious, and the game uses numerous cliches, but for me, it simply worked. The 'paint' and 'painting' theming was well used, and it had some very good set pieces to it.

I do, however, have one major complaint. The game (apparently) has multiple endings based on some of the choices you made during play. This, and how well some of the mementos, drawings and letters were hidden made me feel like the developers were trying to force replayability into a game that, since it's akin to a walk-through haunted house, will never have any.

If you don't mind a few playthroughs to see absolutely everything, and you don't mind an experience that's low on gameplay(like A Machine for Pigs, Dear Esther, or Gone Home) then this is an excellent horror game.

reviewText: This is the first game that I cannot recommend. Yes the visuals are great (though some of the effects break the immersion, especially the plastic-looking black goo that appears in places). It has a great deal of potential, but it just was not well executed. Maybe I have been spoiled by games like Amnesia and Outlast, but the horror elements didn't affect me and it became more of a task to finish than an immersive experience. Half of the problem is the poor control and interaction system. You have to be in very precise locations and at specific angles to interact with the objects, which becomes even more frustrating when you have to open doors through holding a button and rotating/moving. This often became extremely frustrating, since much of the game is just opening doors or drawers.\n\nIf they worked out a better control system and fleshed out the game a bit more, it certainly would be a game to pick up, but right now I cannot recommend it at full or even half price.

Early Access Review

OKAY. Just so we are clear!

I have played many, many, many horror games.... with that being said.

This game is a really solid horror game. I actually really liked this game for being an early access to be completely honest. It's so rare anymore that a game actually gives me chills or makes me second guess what I'm doing or in fact ****ing scare the **** out of me.

Was that supposed to happen? Why did the thing I thought was gonna happen NOT happen? Why is this rooom CONSTANTLY changing on me?!

Everytime I died, or atleast thought I died, I awoke in the same room only to enter a COMPLETELY different room. This made me feel very confused a lot of the time since I had NO idea how this game functions as far as life and death. It's actually refreshing in a game to NOT know if you are doing things right.

Overall, I would rate this game as in it's current state a 8/10.

It has an overall good feel to it. It's interesting. It's crazy. it makes you feel like you are going ****ing insane sometimes. And that's totally what this genre needs in my opinion. I honestly can't wait to play the finnished product. I would reccomend to anyone who wants to play a good horror game.

reviewText:
Layers of Fear follows the struggles of a painter as works to complete one final painting after his life has fallen into ruin. Piecing together layers of fear's story through letters and images is surprisingly fun due to good writing and interesting, well paced plot development. I found myself looking forward to reading each new story fragment. The story is suitably dark, greatly adding to the overall tension of the experience.

Layers of Fear is often terrifying, making good use of well paced and foreshadowed jump scares and thick tension. However, Layers of Fear truly excels when it is most surreal. No frightening moments were quite as memorable as watching furniture swirl around a room to the sound of classical music.

Layers of Fear also bears a strikingly distinct visual style. Hallways are littered with beautiful and bizarre paintings, many of which serve as nice motifs throughout the game. Many of these paintings carry unique and unsettling looks which make them instantly recognizable. Apart from the visual style, Layers of Fear is also one of the best looking games I have ever seen on the Unity engine, and serves as a testament to the power and flexibility of Unity's tool set. Sound design is also good, although it does make use of some fairly familiar noises. They are all well implemented, but be prepared to hear some high pitch screeches and other common horror sounds. One area of the sound design that does not suffer is the music, which always comes on at just the right time. It is peaceful and provides great contrast to the dark atmosphere.

Layers of Fear is a beautiful, surreal, and frightening trip into the mind of a broken man. What it lacks in traditional game-play mechanics it makes up for with a thick atmosphere and a great story.  Any fans of horror games will certainly find a lot to enjoy within Layers of Fear's winding halls.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sB_6mk-XTw

Join a demented artists descent into madness from haunting memories of the past. Layers of Fear takes a similar approach to games such as Penumbra and Amnesia: The Dark Descent as it uses a couple of similar mechanics. The player gets to roam around the artists mansion and uncover small detail on his life before you - the artist begins to reflect on a project that will warp the home into what lurks inside this unhinged man. The game uses excellent timing and scripting that will alter the perception of the artist.
While Layers of Fear has a few things that need to improve as the time I am writing this the studio has done a tremendous job of building up a character and his house with pride only to see the dark depth that lies behind that canvas.

My only gripe and a message to the developer is to add more roaming and utility to the space that is available make the home more than hallway haunted house. The gameplay should give more options for failure and more puzzles to confuse the player and not go through step by step key by door unlock. With that being said Layers of Fear is a psychological horror that paints a beautifully deranged future for the true horror genre. I hope to see more like this from this studio.

NOTE: Do realize this game is in Early Access and is not a finished product. At this time the game will give you around 2.5 hours of gameplay or so and I would expect with the detail given so far that the game will have around 6-7 hours of gameplay time in all with the finished product.

reviewText:
This was definitely one of the scariest games I have played.  I had permanent goosebumps the whole time.  You never know when something freaky might happen so you're on edge all the time.  It's not just standard scary.  It's like fear on drugs.

I really enjoy the story that you piece together as you gather photos and notes from around the house.  You come to find that your character seems to have some seriously dark issues.  And, I've come away still not 100% understanding exactly what happened.  So, I might play again to try to find the notes I missed to piece the whole story together.

I really enjoyed this game, but thought that it was far too short to warrant spending $21.99.

I played this game on my Twitch stream and it only took five hours to complete.  This includes all of the time I chatted with viewers and went on breaks which is quite a lot.

I'd definitely recommend it if it's on sale.   I'd only give it a 60% recommendation if it's not on sale and you really like games like this.

reviewText:
What makes this different compared to other typical horror games is that danger isn't necessarily dangerous. While there are few instances where you will feel threatened with your life, death isn't the end. It's simply another choice. Every cause has an effect, and here you're urged to approach danger with curiosity, not run away in fear. Doing either will lead to a whole other story.

So don't fear the danger, but approach it cautious. Do you want to know what happened to your wife?
There's only one way to find out...






Game highly recommended, I don't regret buying it at full retail and will still say it's worth it. I've played for ten hours after the pre-release and have still not finished, because taking your time, observing your surroundings and searching for the past is the only way you're going to find out what the hell is going on in this place. Not to mention it has high replay value due to the amount of choices one can make to progress the story a little differently each time.

reviewText:
Layers of Reviews
Layers of Fear takes the player into the psyche of an artist so disconnected from the reality, the grahics department of the indie studio Bloober Team gets free hands on their creativity and that truly shows.

Layers of Fear is that one game a seasoned horror movie/video game fan struggles to give a review on. The basics are all there, the atmosphere gives a nod to the very classic style of horror media, the sounds are creeping, and visuals are stunningly detailed.

The overall storyline (no spoilers) follows the line of little breadcrumbs leading into the finale. I'd say the insane artist is portrayed in a very classic manor, kind of reminding me of the Edgar Allan Poe style spooky-spooky readings.

The game did already in Beta/Early Access state leave quite positive feelings regarding the quality of the game, but unfortunately the developer team can't quite capture the very edge of what makes AAA quality horror.

I find that the game has tedious parts where it seems that the game repeats itself too much and the player isn't constantly holding breath for the next big thing. This kind of pacing has it's place, but I feel they've stretched it a tad too far and leaves the player just thinking, how much bigger and more effective could've those parts be.

Credit is due where it shows, or whatever they say about it. This studio has shown it's potential in making a game that plunges into a fresh direction in the otherwise so boring genre. For a beginner of horror game consumption, the number below will be higher for sure.

3.5/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The real horror in this game were the striking similarities it shared with my own life. My growing madness, my hatred of rats, my unfinished opus magnum, my enjoyment of a good drink. Not to mention when ever I walk through a door it always leads somewhere else on the way back.

The game plays like spending 2 hours in a haunted house. While it's no Mc cready manor the atmosphere is worth playing for alone.You wont leave broken and crying but will be taken by the enthralling concept of the painter gone mad. The game attempts to scare players with haunted props and occasionally a monster. However it's hard to be frightened once you look closer and realize the monster and set dressings are made of animatronics and plastic. Since you can't actually be killed and your fate is predetermined you are more of a carnival patron wandering down a set route until your ticket time expires and you're asked to leave.

This doesn't mean the game is bad though, as the ambiance, tone and atmosphere are all very  engaging, enough to keep you immersed and intrigued. The game is surreal utilizing madness/psychedelic visions rather than traditional monster cliches (for the most part). The game looks good and appropriately creepy with it's period decor. While the audio is also strong I'm still not entirely sold on the voice acting. Seeming a little predictable when read out to us, I feel it can slightly hurt the overall mood. The idea being mystery may remain more eerie.The concept it's self of horror revolving around paintings is interesting and well done. Capturing how unsettling these old masters works can be.

With a few more game play elements or perhaps puzzles this experience could be enhanced. As it is now though the game still deserves a play through by fans of surreal horror.

reviewText:
Layers of Fear follows the struggles of a painter as works to complete one final painting after his life has fallen into ruin. Piecing together layers of fear's story through letters and images is surprisingly fun due to good writing and interesting, well paced plot development. I found myself looking forward to reading each new story fragment. The story is suitably dark, greatly adding to the overall tension of the experience.

Layers of Fear is often terrifying, making good use of well paced and foreshadowed jump scares and thick tension. However, Layers of Fear truly excels when it is most surreal. No frightening moments were quite as memorable as watching furniture swirl around a room to the sound of classical music.

Layers of Fear also bears a strikingly distinct visual style. Hallways are littered with beautiful and bizarre paintings, many of which serve as nice motifs throughout the game. Many of these paintings carry unique and unsettling looks which make them instantly recognizable. Apart from the visual style, Layers of Fear is also one of the best looking games I have ever seen on the Unity engine, and serves as a testament to the power and flexibility of Unity's tool set. Sound design is also good, although it does make use of some fairly familiar noises. They are all well implemented, but be prepared to hear some high pitch screeches and other common horror sounds. One area of the sound design that does not suffer is the music, which always comes on at just the right time. It is peaceful and provides great contrast to the dark atmosphere.

Layers of Fear is a beautiful, surreal, and frightening trip into the mind of a broken man. What it lacks in traditional game-play mechanics it makes up for with a thick atmosphere and a great story.  Any fans of horror games will certainly find a lot to enjoy within Layers of Fear's winding halls.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sB_6mk-XTw

Join a demented artists descent into madness from haunting memories of the past. Layers of Fear takes a similar approach to games such as Penumbra and Amnesia: The Dark Descent as it uses a couple of similar mechanics. The player gets to roam around the artists mansion and uncover small detail on his life before you - the artist begins to reflect on a project that will warp the home into what lurks inside this unhinged man. The game uses excellent timing and scripting that will alter the perception of the artist.
While Layers of Fear has a few things that need to improve as the time I am writing this the studio has done a tremendous job of building up a character and his house with pride only to see the dark depth that lies behind that canvas.

My only gripe and a message to the developer is to add more roaming and utility to the space that is available make the home more than hallway haunted house. The gameplay should give more options for failure and more puzzles to confuse the player and not go through step by step key by door unlock. With that being said Layers of Fear is a psychological horror that paints a beautifully deranged future for the true horror genre. I hope to see more like this from this studio.

NOTE: Do realize this game is in Early Access and is not a finished product. At this time the game will give you around 2.5 hours of gameplay or so and I would expect with the detail given so far that the game will have around 6-7 hours of gameplay time in all with the finished product.

reviewText:
I approached this game not as a survival horror junkie looking for my next sleepless night fix like Amnesia or SOMA, but more about the main protagonist’s tragic story, along the lines of Dear Esther and Gone Home. And it’s brilliant. The game is an interactive story novel rather than a game with a challenge, and there’s no losing condition whatsoever. However finding more clues can alter which ending you receive.

On that note, finding clues throughout the game provides a cryptic non-direct story telling narrative that heavily suggests (however doesn’t directly imply) what happened to the painter’s family, the loss of his muse, his downfall from the peak of his career, the impact it had on his mental psyche, his marriage, the toll on his mental health, until its ultimate tragic conclusion and the painter’s failure to cope with it. The result of which being his extreme mental illness entailing hallucination, schizophrenia, masochism, etc. We as the player are invited to see his extremely warped mental mind as he strives to complete his Magnum Opus in hopes that will cure him of his insanity and the suffering he’s endured will be worth it. Or will it? The narrative leaves out just enough for us on purpose to fill in the pieces about what really happened.

As an artist myself I could sympathize with the loss of the painter’s muse and his absolute frustration on why he couldn’t seem to pull it back together. Something like that has got to be incredibly self-defeating, where one minute the painter is at the top of his career, and in the next it’s all taken away and he loses his creative drive to continue his work, winding up with lackluster paintings panned by critics, which set the tragic stage for everything else to follow.

The horror elements provided in the game are good, however they do get repetitive towards the end. However I think that’s the point. We the player begin to feel numb and desensitized from the horror presented in the game just like the painter, as that’s his and our way of coping through this new warped mental normality that he’s constructed. Despite all that’s happening around him, he presses onward determined to finish his painting.

An excellent tragic horror story worth anyone’s time to delve into the mind of a fallen artist.

Early on in this game I got an achievement called Wanderer." Apt.

I bought this game based purely on my love for horror and the overwhelmingly positive reviews. What a total flop of a game and a waste of my money.

I didn't find any terror in this game -- just plenty of attempts at cheap jump scares. Wandering the mansion is mind-numbing. The textures
recommended: and sounds are repetitive. The pace of the game is infuratingly slow. I finished the thing in a wholehearted attempt to find some redeeming quality but as you can guess there was no redeeming quality.\n\nThe game is a design nightmare -- and certainly not the good kind of nightmare. From a technical standpoint
hoursPlayed: nearly every drawer and cabinet in the game is openable. What's in the drawers? Sunglasses. Books about pandas. Inkwells. War medals. A red herring is fine every once in a great while but sheesh. To open a drawer or a door you have to hold down the trigger on your controller and twist the thumbstick awkwardly. A useless mechanic that adds to the monotony. Save that stuff for Quicktime Events. The game is equally broken from a storytelling standpoint. The letters and drawings are full of tired attemps at dark humor and trite metaphors. The story isn't even especially interesting. There are no puzzles. "Gone Home" is a walking simulator done the best a walking simulator can be done. This is a walking simulator that epitomises the failure of the genre.\n\nA total dissapointment. I'm astounded at how many people love this thing. Is this the "Friends" of the horror video game genre?"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, my experiences with Layers of Fears has been an EXCEPTIONALLY Good one. For it being just $10'ish is a steal, for those that love Frictional Games and their style of psychological horror - you will find yourself at home with this game.

The quality, the physics and ability to open things and investigate would remind you easily of Amnesia - the voice acting is great and the overall atmosphere is stunning. The choice, methods and timing of the 'Spooks' are pretty impressive in my books, not many can pull off an environment that makes you immerse yourself almost to the same levels as PS4's P.T. Demo.

No but seriously, the game is freaking BEAUTIFUL to look at. Few minor flaws may include a very minimal amount of Graphical options beyond it detecting your Resolution, a run of the mill visual setting and the detection of what Hz your monitor is running at - Those who love tweaking their settings or perhaps with low-range computers may run into trouble unless I'm wrong about this games' optimization on lower settings.

Summary: For a game that's 75% done, supposedly, is perhaps so far around 3-4+ hours long, and at the price of $10. This game is completely worth it. $10 is a steal, the price WILL raise when more content is added and as more time passes by so I'd argue that it'd be the best decision to buy it, play it, enjoy it and support the developers. If they were to be successful with this game and get good profit? Would could say otherwise that we may just have Another great studio who're capable of making horror games like Frictional Games - We need more developers like those two. Saying that they remind me of Frictional is one of the best compliments I can give to devs who're doing the Horror genre.

If you'd like to see for yourself, the quality and my playthrough, I have a Let's Play series of this game being created as we speak! If interested, hope you all enjoy!

reviewText:
WARNING : WARNING : WARNING : WARNING

Controls are completely broken since the March update. (Both Mouse AND controller). Both Axes on Mouse and Controller are different speeds with the Y-axis about 2-3 times faster than the X-axis. The X-axis speed is also tied to your frame-rate now and will change depending on how high or low your frame-rate is at the time. There is also now a turn-speed limit with the mouse no matter how high the sensitivity is set.
It was a feat to finish this game and this issue has sucked much of the enjoyment out of it since struggling with controls kills immersion. Considering the controls were pretty much perfect in the older versions it boggles the mind how they could have botched them up this badly with a single update.

Wait until a patch to fix controls is implemented or find a way to get your hands on an earlier version.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Layers of Fear, at first, felt like an Amnesia rip off, with the hand gestures and such but it's quite unique. I admit I did not know what I was letting myself in for when I played the first five minutes but it was an absolute treat. The physiological horror element is enough to rattle anyone up. The imagery was spectacular as you follow this artists’ journey into madness, picking up clues from the past and reacquainted with it, literally!

As I have said, the imagery is brilliant. Never going off key, staying relevant to our protagonist. It is almost like dipping into the mind of a troubled painter, to which it is obvious that he is facing some difficulties, not to mention a bad drinking habit – bottles, bottles everywhere!

It has this Alice in Wonderland type style to which works to this game’s advantage and is worryingly addictive! I cannot wait for the game to be completed. At the moment there is around 3 hours of gameplay (Depends how slow and scared you are!) and from what I have gathered, around 3 more hours before the game is Officially over.

I don’t want to give too much away, the game does rely on surprise and the unexpected. The only way of finding out is to play the game for yourself. It is worth it!

reviewText:
I normally don't like horror games, or this type of gameplay. But just seeing someone else play this, I felt drawn to it. I took a chance. It was well worth it.

There are things I could nitpick about the graphics, the length, and the replay value, but I don't want to. The game's faults are tiny. The important thing is, there are moments in this game that feel like the nightmares I had after seeing The Shining for the first time. There are gorgeous, mind-warping, Escher-esque moments that are as effective as any bit of visual storytelling I've ever seen. Not just jump scares, but subtle moments that will make you doubt your perceptions and sanity.

I could gripe about how Layers Of Fear can be extremely linear, to the point where the moments of actual gameplay and choice can be few and far between. But it works. It creates a sense of helplessness that adds to the the dread. And it makes you pay special attention to the few choices you do have.

I think this is less of a game than an experience. A halfway point between 'game' and 'movie'. It's like the developers looked at Gone Home and P.T., saw two unfinished concepts, and squeezed them together into one. I love the result.

Plus, it's just so damn luscious to look at.

reviewText:
Let's start off with the good things;

The visuals in this game were gorgeous, and the sound design is pretty good as well.

Now to the main problems;

Length: 3-4 hours...eh.

Repetitiveness: For a 3-4 hour game, there are far too many reused assets. I can understand that developers need to recycle objects, but that you keep running past the same paintings literally dozens of times just seems lazy.

Story: Cliché all the way. You literally see it coming from miles away. There is no intrigue or twists, no surprises, no innovation whatsoever.

Scare-o-meter: This should probably be the most important factor for any potential buyer. To put it bluntly, the game just isn't frightening (unless you count the 3-5 jumpscares, which frankly I don't). I was actually bored at times. Again, I can't stretch this enough, I was bored playing a Horror game. This is not because I'm some tough-as-nails ubergangster, quite the opposite, I'm actually suffering from advanced stages of ♥♥♥♥♥fication. The problem is that, very early on, I realised that nothing can harm you in this game. With nothing to be afraid of, you will become completely detached and all immersion goes out the window. Ultimately, I just went through the motions and finished the game purely because I wanted to see the final version of the artist's painting.

In Summation: If you want to play a tense Horror title, go for Amnesia: The Dark Descent (stay away from A Machine for Pigs, though) or Outlast (the Whistleblower DLC is worth it as well).

If you want to look at pretty setpieces for 3-4 hours, and holy ♥♥♥♥, pretty they are, play Layers of Fear. But do yourself a favor and pick it up when it's on sale.

Pardon the bad pun, but this game is a work of art. It is a game that attempts to tap in to the deepest darkest parts of the human psychie and take you to places where your sanity dare not follow you. From what I have experienced thus far, this game transcends a lot of the externalistically framed horror cleches and instead twists such ideas in a unique way that presents you with the most personal and horrific idea of all: what dark secrets lay waiting within me?

Along with brilliant proof of concept, the strangly alluring yet spine tingling atmosphere in this game rivals that of all past successful modern horror games, such as Outlast, Alien Isolation, etc. Although still in Alpha and not yet completed, this is one masterpeice all horror gaming fans must own!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A psychological horror game /walking simulator.
It is sometimes detrimental to compare one game to another, but this reminds of a mash up of Gone Home and Amnesia:dark descent. Player is guided through the labyrinthine corridors and rooms of the protaganists home/mind, discovering clues and objects that go some way to explain the unfolding of events. Unrelentlessy claustrophobic each twist and turn brings BOO scares, morphing architecture and paintings and surreal imagery.
So is it any good? In its current Early Access state, answer is a reserved Yes.
Some of the scenes are chilling haunting and genuinely surprising. Where the game is subtle is where it mosts succeeds; was that a human shadow flitting accross the corridor? a figure through the rain lashed window pane illuminated by lightning? The atmosphere is well managed, there is no escape from the tension and the dread of turning round opening a door or turning a corner is all pervasive.
On the downside, there are far too many jump scares that ,yes, scare the beejezus outta you, but quickly become the norm, and start to feel a little cheap in consequence.
There were some events" I surely missed because the game did not attract my attention to the occurence
date: although the sound track indicated something had happened The story up to this point is underdeveloped
recommended: and although I felt in the most part immersed in the game this is despite of the story line rather than because of it.\nDespite the usual old horror tropes that don't bring anything "new" to the game genre
hoursPlayed: if you don't mind jump scares and a linear gameplay
voteText: then give this one a go.\n6.5-7/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pardon the bad pun, but this game is a work of art. It is a game that attempts to tap in to the deepest darkest parts of the human psychie and take you to places where your sanity dare not follow you. From what I have experienced thus far, this game transcends a lot of the externalistically framed horror cleches and instead twists such ideas in a unique way that presents you with the most personal and horrific idea of all: what dark secrets lay waiting within me?

Along with brilliant proof of concept, the strangly alluring yet spine tingling atmosphere in this game rivals that of all past successful modern horror games, such as Outlast, Alien Isolation, etc. Although still in Alpha and not yet completed, this is one masterpeice all horror gaming fans must own!

reviewText:
“Every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of the artist, not of the sitter.” - Oscar Wilde.

'Layers of Fear' is not so much a 'game' as it is more of an 'experience' The player finds themselves in the tourted shoes of a freelance artist.

You will spend the majority of your time stumbling all around his mansion, as the world literally, falls apart around you. With the world constantly changing and the pace fluctuating akin to Bill Clinton taking a lie detector test, you hardly find time to appreciate the stunning graphics Layers of Fear has to offer. The experience itself is similar to paying twenty dollars to visit a haunted house attraction, albeit an absolutely spectacular one. This is, without any hint of doubt, the game 'Silent Hills' (May it rest in peace) would have been.

To elaborate on the semiotic conventions of this game, one would be forced to spoil the story. So to avoid any spoilers I shall say just this:
There is a fine line between reality and one's subconscious. However
recommended: you must play the game to find out"\n\nIn conclusion. If you have even a inkling of interest for psychological horrors
hoursPlayed: purchase his immediately and...Don't Look Back.\n"

reviewText: This was a pretty creepy game, although I feel I should mention that my personality seems to greatly reduce the effect that horror games have on me; I often find humor in the things that are supposed to be frightening.\nLet's say for example, you walk up to a door to open it or whatever. As you turn the knob, instead of the door gently swinging open (which is a normal behavior for doors), it is suddenly torn away by some unseen force and smashes violently into the wall ahead of you. Creepy, right? Not if your brain automatically imagines that the protagonist just gained superpowers and thunder-punched the door into oblivion.\nBut yeah, it's still one of the better horror games I've played, and if you're looking for a good horror game to play for a few hours, get this one.

reviewText:
Well.. im certainly glad i got this game for free... i feel like i would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if i had just paid 20 dollars for this.

Short run through of what you will experience..

Starting out you wonder around searching for things that might be useful.
The limited yet effecient tutorial pop ups show you everything you need to
know to play the dame.. cause you literally only need to be able to walk and
pull the right trigger... you dont believe the tutorial so you search around for
a while before you realize that there isnt really anything to do... you grab (Spoiler)
and move on.

Chapter one... (Walking simulator)

You are guided on a linear tour of a magical ever changing house that attemtps
to scare you more and more as time goes on. You move from room to room hesitantly
opening objects and slowly peeking around corners scared for you life...

As you move from room to room you find yourself in a repeatative simulation of walking
through hallways.. that have 1 of 3 outcomes

1. Nothing and you move on
2. Scary thing
3. Something to pick up / read

You also learn that if there is somethign to pick up you cant go through the door until you do
You then learn that there are times when the scary thing" doesnt just go away and the
"scary thing" jumps at you and you wake up somewhere else.. learning that... you cant die.

from the information attained above you deduce that there is no recourse for just running through
rooms. and you develop a routine...

First thing check the doors.. if ones unlocked you can just move on cause there isnt really anthing important
if all exits are locked... look for somethign to pick up.. if nothing can be picked up there will probably be
a scary part and then you will either be able to pick something up or move on through a newly unlocked
door... thats it..

and since you cant die.. you can essentially just spam through it.. becuase you have learned that there
really isnt anything important to do.. so.. you just keep moving..

serious lack of player incentive.
Making a way to die would be nice.

Its essentially the equivelent on walking through a haunted house... you know nothing really bad is going
to happen.. so there really isnt anything to be sdcared of...

some aspects were cool..
most of it i just found myself bored..
i only jumped 3 times.. and most if not all of that was probably due to the loud sounds and headphones
being too loud.

if you are easily scared by games... get this... it inst worth 20 dollars though... 10 at MOST and thats stretching it.
5.99 is a good price. its just too short to be worth 20 dollars.. (yeah there are multipler endings.. but honestly..
without the threat of dieing.. i cant really be bothered to walk around looking for items to pick up that change the
story in someway. i know i will be able to do it no problem without dieing. So whats the point."
