reviewText:
Few games display the brand of their engine right in their main title card. Layers of Fear does, and it's easy to see why. The game is a tour-de-force of the latest and greatest Unity 5 graphics and physics features, and looks gorgeous. The Victorian house the game is set in is a beautiful design, with supremely moody lighting and decoration.

You play as a tormented, peglegged painter deliriously shuffling through both your memories and the building itself, turning the place upside down while rummaging the rooms filled with snippets of the past. The mansion gradually turns into a representation of your psyche as you venture deeper into mania, with walls closing in and rooms rearranging themselves.

Because you can never construct a mental map of the house, exploration isn't a thing in Layers of Fear. Quite contrary, your progression is extremely one-tracked. The process of opening cupboards, drawers and doors imitates the Frictional Engine style of tactility, but gameplay-wise there's not much else to do. The game could be compared to a fairground ghost train that steadily chugs along, with a fright at every turn. And therein lies its greatest folly: Oversaturation of cheap jumpscares.

Layers of Fear is filled to the brim with startles, dissonant chords, stuff shoved at your face and loud things going bang in the night -- So much that it very quickly becomes predictable and completely loses its effect. The backstory is told with promising subtlety, but it gets drowned in the constant jolts the game feels necessary to administer in clockwork fashion.

Despite its technical merits, Layers of Fear is clear disappointment; It simply tries too hard. A little restraint would've gone a long way.

reviewText:
This game started out very much like Amnesia:The Dark Descent, creepy victorian mansion that is empty and full of creepy mystery. I was super stoked to get throught it; but then everything went bad. The scares just weren't there due to a huge lack of ambience, the game recommends to have headphones in but all that accomplished was blasting high pitched notes into my eardrums occasionally and other loud noises to make me jump. In case the devs are reading this LOUD NOISES=/=SCARY just because you make someone jump doesn't give the same sense of dread as having good ambient sound design.

Not to mention it was a really big pile of horror tropes from other games stitched together, erratic shifting monster? check. Victorian dolls? check. changing environment? check. and you know I was expecting it to be a little bit more of a complex story, seeing as this is just gone home with ghosts basically, but all I got was a fairly mediocre story of artist gone crazy. (Using body parts for the art was especially cheesy)

So no, for $7 an hour for pretty lame scares you should just go see a movie or something instead.

5/10 2 points were added for the werebaby which was the main reason I chose to write a review.

reviewText: The game tries to be scary. It tries really, really hard. So hard that it ends up not scary at all. While the visuals are stunning, the game itself is not so much a horror game as a museum of horror game tropes. Remember that creepy thing you saw in that game? It's here. You walk from one room to another, wondering what kind of a jump-scare or a mind-screw they'll throw at you this time. Will it be a sudden bloody knife? A woman's shout? A wheelchair following you? A door you open to see a gigantic face staring at you?\nThe problem is, all these special effects are there on their own, existing for their own sake. In Silent Hill, Clocktower, Fatal Frame they served a purpose. Here the excuse plot is so formulaic I can't care about the story or the people. So, while you might enjoy the attractions, there's nothing else to it -- lots of hard work and artistic talent put into creation of a catalogue of cliches.

reviewText:
I hobble into the foyer of what is presumably my own house, a dim light and occasional cracks of lightning are all I have to navigate. The paintings’ grotesque smiles seem to be aimed at me. Unsettling, calm music is playing from a gramophone somewhere upstairs. The door to the bathroom is half-open and I don’t really want to look inside. These are the first five minutes of Layers of Fear. These are the best minutes of Layers of Fear.

The game is packed full of horror clichés that were never too scary to begin with, and become less and less frightening every time they’re used. Sure, seeing a fractured porcelain doll once might be a bit weird. When the game is packed with them, at one point literally swarming with them, it’s just not effective. Any potentially effective scares are ruined by the fact that everything is fired off in a rapid succession, demonstrating a lack of understanding on what makes horror great. Most of the horror isn’t even the scare itself, it’s the buildup, waiting for something to happen. As Alfred Hitchcock once said, “There is no horror in the bang, only in the anticipation of it.” I couldn’t put it better myself.

Read the full review at: http://techraptor.net/content/layers-of-fear-review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game really surprised me in more ways than one.It absolutely lives up to it's name. It is freaky and scary , and even has a story line that becomes more and more apparent as you progress through the game. I was jump scared far more in this game than any game of this genre ever, and I don't scare easily. I highly recommend it , even though it is in Early Access, because I just know these guys are going to make this game a gem , and really, it already is. I just can't wait until the next addition and/or full release to arrive. This is one I'll play more than once or twice. Great job on this one. I give it a solid 10/10.

A quick add: I'll bet this one will be played mostly during daylight hours. This one will scare a lot of people that normally aren't skittish. Night play in this game is much more scary.

reviewText: This game freaked me out--I thought I was going to die because the design is so dull. Most linear game I've ever played, literally. This is no hyperbole, the game would shuffle you through a series of rooms and not even let you turn around because it would lock every door behind you and have the architecture change almost every time you turn around (so spooky). Bad lighting, too: I had to play in the dark not to increase the horror factor (of which there is none, and this comes from someone who cries when playing Silent Hill), but to be able to see anything. Finicky controls; closing the elevator door is really a ploy to give you carpal tunnel. It's unclear what items are interactive, forcing you to scroll randomly about the room.\n\nLong story short, you've experienced the game's full repetoire of tricks after an hour's play. $20 is a joke for the reasons outlined above, and I never even broached the ridiculously basic design of the house through which you roam. It reminded me of something I would create absent-mindedly as a child while playing Sims: Livin' It Up. I do feel obliged to say in the game's defence, especially after so damning a comment, that there was the occasional visual trick that is impressive. Not enough to earn your dollar, though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has some worthwhile content, but the lack of tension and other issues prevent an immersive experience.

Pros
-Great concept
-Cool art
-Controls/mechanics on point
-early access' version of the plot has convinced me that the full story is going to be cool

Cons
-Lackluster sound design
-The poorly designed NPC, esp in the needless close ups. Wouldn't scare a toddler
-Zero tension thanks in part to the total lack of risk in doing any action
-Zero challenge, easy puzzles

Suggestions
-hopefully mirrors will work in full version
-more surround sound stuff
-get rid of NPC close-ups or make them remotely cool
-rethink the mixing of voice actor audio
-do more to play with the graphical glitches in subtle ways to disorient the player
-make the walk/run speed slower to increase anticipation/tension

In its current state I'd give LoF 6/10 strips of flayed skin
